—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer him to Senator Button's statement last week that he, Senator Button, would prefer a United States dollar-Australian dollar exchange rate of US65c to US68c. Is it the policy of the Government to induce a further depreciation of the Australian dollar in coming months? If so, why was this strategy not outlined in the Budget Papers? If it is not the Government's policy, does the Prime Minister consider it appropriate for Senator Button to express such strong views on the value of the Australian dollar? Finally, as the Budget was framed on the assumption of a US dollar-Australian dollar exchange rate of around 72c, what impact would the realisation of Senator Button's preferred exchange rate have on the Budget forecasts for inflation, the current account deficit and the so-called balanced Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. Let me say that it is not the intention of the Government to try to produce any particular result in regard to the level of the dollar. I used somewhat colourful but I think direct language when I said, `When you float the dollar it bloody floats'. And it does.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say this in regard to the statement of Senator Button, as I have said publicly: what Senator Button was saying was nothing more than a statement of the obvious; that is, that exporters, whether they be manufacturers or exporters of primary products, obviously, as a matter of economic benefit, would be happier with a lower level of the dollar. That is merely a statement of the obvious. It was not an intention by the Minister to speak the dollar down; nor was it so regarded by me. He indicated to me in conversation that he made the observation, in fact, in a background discussion with, I think it was, three United States journalists. Indeed, as he pointed out to me, it was put in the context of referring to the statement that I had made-the one to which I have just referred.

As to the other part of the question by the Leader of the Opposition, which relates to the assumptions upon which the Budget was framed, nothing that has happened or that I expect to happen leads me to expect that the assumption upon which the Budget was framed will be other than accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon a parliamentary delegation from the Federal Republic of Germany led by Dr Walter Wallmann, President of the Bundesrat and Premier of Hesse, and Dr Wolfgang Gerhardt, member of the Bundesrat, Commissioner of Hesse in Bonn and Minister of State for Science and Arts. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to the members of the delegation.
—Can the Prime Minister inform the House of any progress in the emigration of Soviet Jews from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Dunkley for his question. I am sure that in the answer that I give I will have the support of the whole of the House. The Government, since its election in 1983, Madam Speaker, as you know, has made clear to the Soviet Government its concern about human rights in the Soviet Union, including the important question of the rights of Soviet Jews. The latest figures to hand show that 782 Soviet Jews were granted exit permission in August of 1987, bringing the total for the year to 4,681. Jewish emigration since April has averaged about 800 per month. Of course, this is a very welcome advance on the total of 914 for all of 1986 but is less than the 2,000 per month allowed to leave during the 1970's.

ANSWER.PARA: On 8 September the Soviet authorities gave permission to emigrate to a further group of 10 long term refuseniks, including, Madam Speaker, three from the list which you handed over in Moscow in July of 1986. Those three are Dr Prestin, Dr Josef Begun and Dr Brailovsky. I know, Madam Speaker, that that will be a matter of particular joy and pleasure to you. Equally, today I am delighted to say that I have been informed that Ida Nudel, the prominent woman Jewish activist about whom you and the Government have made representations, has received permission to leave the Soviet Union. This brings to eight the number of cases from your list of 18 which have been positively resolved.

In conjunction with Mr Shevardnadze's visit to Australia, a family reunion list was handed to Soviet officials. That list contained 52 cases involving 124 family members. On 23 July the Soviet Embassy passed over in response a list covering 89 individuals who were being permitted to depart. A number of these individuals were of Jewish background. The Soviet authorities have since allowed a smaller number of other cases from that list, including at least one of Jewish origin, to depart. The Government is encouraged by and welcomes-as I know all members of the House will-the developments which are taking place. We will continue to pursue this important issue of principle vigorously with the Soviet Union. The Foreign Minister and I will certainly be taking it up when we visit the Soviet Union later this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to a report in the Australian Financial Review on 2 October 1987 that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy `has been warned by the Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics that the Australian dollar is substantially undervalued in real terms and could rise to at least 80 US cents'. I ask the Prime Minister: How can one reconcile the substantially different views on the value of the dollar emanating from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce?

—The Leader of the Opposition seems to have some difficulty in comprehending what Senator Button said. Given his performance over the last couple of years in matters economic, that is not something about which we should be surprised. Whereas previously in the dim dark days he gave some indication of having a grasp of economic realities and even some commitment to economic rationality, all that has long since passed. For his edification I remind him once again of what Senator Button said. He said no more than that it would be a matter of pleasure and indeed of profit-perhaps the two are synonymous-to exporters in this country if the dollar were to be at a significantly lower level than it is. That is indisputably correct. That would be a matter of pleasure and profit to them. Senator Button was not seeking to talk down the dollar to that figure, nor I suggest was he saying that that is the level at which it would be. The level to which the exchange rate will go is a legitimate matter for differences of opinion. Indeed, without going into any detail or revealing confidences, I can say that at the time that we were considering floating the dollar, the then head of the Treasury, who is now one of the colleagues of the Leader of the Opposition, argued very strongly against it-which I suggest is not a sign of economic perspicacity. One of the reasons he put was that he expected that the dollar, if floated, would in fact increase significantly in value. This is an area in which in the last two or three years all economic commentators have been conspicuously at variance in their predictions of what would happen to the dollar. It does not surprise me that somewhere within the government bureaucracy there may be some who hold the view that has been alluded to by the Leader of the Opposition. The fact that that view has been expressed does nothing to detract from the answer that I previously gave him.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Consumer Affairs and refer him to a report in the June/July edition of the journal Australian Productivity, which he will be aware is published by the Australian Productivity Council. I specifically refer to the claim that Australia is very lowly regarded by Europeans as a nation that produces quality goods. In view of that claim, I ask the Minister what plans he has to assist in this Government's objective and desire to lift exports, but more importantly to lift the quality of Australian manufactured products?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Capricornia for his question and remark to the House on his involvement in consumer issues, in Queensland in particular, and also on this issue which he has raised with me on other occasions. I have noticed the article. It is a very important article which I may take the chance to distribute to honourable members on both sides of the House as soon as I can get enough copies of it from the Australian Productivity Council.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Holley, the Executive Director, made some quite important comments in that document relating to Australia's perceived performance by other countries, particularly European, at the World Economic Forum held in Switzerland a short while ago. Australia was rated 21 out of the 22 countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development for its outward orientation in international trade activity. I think that is something about which all members of this House will be concerned, as should be all Australians, and importantly those in industry.

We do recognise the need to promote Australian goods vigorously not only in Australia but also overseas, and to be seen as a producer of high quality goods. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has made considerable comments about this, as has the Minister for Science and Small Business on many occasions.

In Europe and Japan the quality of goods is quite an obsession. That is to be expected where wage and other costs are high. In a competitive environment quality becomes a determinant for consumers when they are looking for goods to buy. Quality makes a virtue out of necessity, or, indeed, a necessity out of virtue. Quality is of mutual advantage both to the consumer and to industry. I hope that in the coming years-hopefully in the coming months-the idea of quality will be taken up not only by industry but also by consumers in regard to what they purchase and particularly in regard to what they seek from Australian goods.

Senator Button has on many occasions made mention of the fact that when people overseas go to the shelves in their shops and pick up something that is labelled `Made in Australia', the implication in their minds should be that it is a quality product. I believe that consumers in Australia also have a role to play in developing the quality ethos in Australian manufacturing. Consumer demand is--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition obviously is not interested in quality, but this Government is interested in it. Not only is it a quality government, but also it is interested in Australian manufacturers producing quality goods for sale overseas and in Australia. Consumer awards were announced in the Budget under my portfolio. I hope to involve business, the media and unions, as well as consumer groups, in developing an ethos for quality goods in Australia, to the mutual advantage of industry and consumers. Consumers should be able to know what business, the media and unions consider to be quality goods. I hope that in future the Opposition will pay more attention to quality in manufacturing in Australia and encourage its friends in business to take up that challenge.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister intend to propose to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM) which is to be held in Vancouver next week specific measures which the Commonwealth might adopt to seek to achieve a speedy and just resolution of the Fijian crisis? If so, can he outline those measures to the House?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I treat it with the seriousness with which I know it is put. I will put to CHOGM the same things we had to say to the meeting of the South Pacific Forum. At that meeting the countries more immediately and directly concerned with Fiji agreed that the resolution of the tragedy that has occurred within Fiji must ultimately be a matter for the Fijians themselves. All members of the Forum were prepared to provide their good offices. It was suggested that I might go there with the Prime Minister of the Solomon Islands, but we were not going there with some suggestion that we, as outsiders, would have a formula to impose upon Fiji. I believe that this matter will be discussed by CHOGM and that the same attitude will prevail at that meeting. I believe that there would be some statement of principle of concern as to developments in Fiji, and that we would provide to the participants at CHOGM the best information that we have about the developments and the discussions that we have been able to have.

ANSWER.PARA: The central point that I would convey to the honourable member is that we will continue to say that the only source of legitimate authority that we recognise in Fiji is the Governor-General. I believe that the honourable member who asked the question would agree with me that the Governor-General is to be congratulated for the strength, determination and tenacity that he has shown in very difficult times. I am sure that the Commonwealth will take the view that there should be a statement of principle expressing the very strong view that there should be a return to the parliamentary system of democracy. I believe that that will be the attitude of the Commonwealth; it is certainly what we will be putting. Should those in Fiji believe that there could be some role undertaken by the Commonwealth, I have no doubt that those attending CHOGM would be prepared to provide that. I conclude, as I began, by saying that in the end we must recognise that the working out of the situation in Fiji must ultimately be something that is resolved by the Fijians themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy outline the outcome for the dairy industry of the recent meeting of agricultural Ministers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I understand his interest, along with that of several other honourable members, in the dairy industry. The Australian Agricultural Council met last Friday basically to discuss whether we should continue with the levy. Because the New South Wales Minister had invoked the comfort clause we had to come to a decision about the matter. At the outset of the meeting I read a statement and the meeting was then cleared of officials and others. Following that, the Minister from New South Wales, Mr Hallam, announced that he was withdrawing his application for the revocation of the comfort clause. We had a very full and constructive discussion about the realities in the dairy industry-the reality of its structure, the fact that that structure varies between States, the reality of the international market situation and the reality of New Zealand and closer economic relations. For the first time the States did not simply buck pass to the Commonwealth the overall problem of production that has to be exported. I believe that that marked a change from the usual way these matters are handled at Agricultural Council meetings.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been many discussions at various levels, including the industry level. I must pay tribute to the Chairman of the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation, Mr Pat Rowley, who has been trying to put together co-operative arrangements between the industries to take into account what I describe as some of the ultimate realities in this industry. Ministers Hallam and Walker from New South Wales and Victoria respectively are also prepared to engage in very constructive and co-operative arrangements involving the industry in an effort to get some discipline, to get a more sensible way of handling the transfer of milk interstate on some regulated basis rather than simply having mavericks determine the pace of what will eventually be a broader reality. Products-even milk-can freely cross State borders by arrangement. We need to have some means whereby that can be done in a controlled and disciplined fashion so the interests of producers and consumers can be looked after. It was a very constructive meeting and I believe that there is a chance that this matter can be resolved on a co-operative basis involving industry and perhaps, at the end of the day, involving some market sharing, with people fully understanding what realities they face.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories will recall his election promise that funding for the tourism overseas promotion scheme (TOPS) would be nearly doubled. Does the Minister know that when TOPS was abolished his Department was processing applications worth $15m, applications which complied with the Government's guidelines and which he promised would be processed immediately? In view of the fact that the industry committed funds in good faith and submitted applications following his campaign promise, what compensation will the Government pay for the breaking of that promise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for the first question he has asked me in his new role. First of all, I do not recall any election promise about doubling the funds for TOPS. Certainly statements have been made by me prior to the election, at various forums, that the Government had committed $9m for the provision of TOPS payments for the year 1987-88. I might inform the honourable member that, despite the fact that the Government has decided to discontinue TOPS, that promise will be honoured, and $9m has been made available-$6m to honour commitments made with ministerial approval and the additional $3m for the Australian Tourist Commission for additional promotion.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the shadow Minister, who is the new boy on the block, that that question coming from his side of the House about tourism promotion seems to be rather inappropriate. Although his glorious Leader might laugh, I note that when he was the Treasurer the commitment to tourism of governments ahead of the Hawke Government was zilch or zilch minus. His great achievement in seven years of government was to allow the Tourist Commission to stagnate with barely an increase in funds in comparison with the trebling of funds under this Government, to introduce a sales tax on the building of tourist boats which stopped an industry stone dead and which fortunately this Government reversed retrospectively to the day of its introduction, and to introduce a $20 departure tax which this Government has seen fit not to increase. That is his glorious record in tourism promotion, so a question from his side of the House on tourism promotion is quite inappropriate.

In addition, I might point out that one of the first statements the Leader of the Opposition made in the election campaign was to the effect that, in government, his side of the House, his parties, would eliminate my Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism, which statement was greeted with not only alarm but also quiet amusement by all sections of the tourism industry. It was well known also that he had made the statement that, in government, he would totally remove $1.2 billion worth of industry assistance provided by this Government. So, it is fairly obvious to everybody in the tourism industry that TOPS would have been eliminated anyhow.

Tourism has become the biggest industry in Australia, greatly to the credit of this Government, which has supported and recognised its extraordinary potential. The fact that we have removed TOPS is to me a matter of personal regret but it is a fact of reducing government expenditure. TOPS was an open-ended scheme which could have led to extraordinary outlays in government finance. Most members of the tourism industry have suggested to me since that they expected that it would happen. The tourism industry is now in a very healthy, comfortable position, having a prosperity they would not have dreamed of four or five years ago. They are quite happy that the Government's decision to remove TOPS and to invest that money in other activities of the Tourist Commission was a proper one.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Speaker, I seek leave to table a document which confirms the existence of that commitment--
—I am not sure whether my question should be directed to the Prime Minister or the Minister for Community Services and Health.
—The honourable member should make up his mind.

—It is regarding the ID card. In view of the fact that Mr Ewart Smith has so demoralised the Opposition that Question Time has become a bit of a farce today, what has been the Government's decision regarding the ID card?
—To whom did you finally decide to address the question?
—The Prime Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I announced that in the light of the position that we would not be able to proceed with the Australia Card. Given the indication by the Senate vote-I think it was 40 : 30-of its intention to proceed by way of disallowing regulations, we decided not to go ahead with the Australia Card. We have decided to investigate the possibility of using the tax file number system. I might say that it is very interesting to see what has happened with the Opposition on this issue. I remind the House of what happened when this matter was before the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. All Opposition members were party to the majority recommendation. I know the honourable member would be interested to be reminded of these extracts from the majority recommend- ation from chapter 4 which is headed `Alternatives'. This is what the Opposition was party to:

ANSWER.PARA: 10. That legislation be enacted to require financial institutions to provide information reported to the Australian Taxation Office in an acceptable format.
Then paragraph 12 states:

12. (a) That the use of the tax file number be extended to cover all the financial transactions proposed in the Government submission for use of the Australia Card number by the Australian Taxation Office, as well as for social security purposes.
(d) That the integrity of the tax file number be upgraded to that of the proposed Australia Card number based on the following premises:
(i) that taxpayers with a continuous tax record exceeding five years not be required to make an application;
(ii) that the file numbers of these taxpayers be verified by normal audit processes over a period of time;
(iii) that all other taxpayers and persons who do not currently possess a tax file number verify their identity to the same level of integrity as proposed under the Australia Card program;
(iv) that the interview process for verifying identity be conducted by the Department of Social Security or nominated agents; and
(v) that temporary arrangements be made where necessary to facilitate payment of tax before verification of identity.

That was the unanimous decision of members of the Opposition on the Joint Select Committee. As a Government having been denied by the Opposition the possibility of going ahead with a system of the greatest integrity, we shall now pursue our investigation of the use of the tax file numbering system and we shall investigate it, certainly in the light of the observations of the Joint Select Committee. I must say, though, that increasingly those opposite are starting to look very tatty indeed. I remind those opposite that it really is a case of the leopard not being able to change its spots. Madam Speaker, you do not have to rely on a judgment from this side of the House about the record of the Liberal-National Party Government on the question of tax avoidance and evasion. In 1981 its own royal commissioner condemned it for its record over the preceding five years when he said that in that five years the tax avoidance industry was the fastest growing industry in the country. When the Opposition was in government it allowed tax avoidance to become the fastest growth industry. It has stopped this Government bringing in the system of the greatest integrity-the Australia Card. Now it looks as though the Opposition, having given its unanimous approval to the upgraded tax file system in the report of the Joint Select Committee, in pursuit of its tatty political opportunism will try to stop that too. Once again, the people will make their judgment about the Opposition and it will be condemned, as it should be.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Does the Remuneration Tribunal's 1986 review state, for the purposes of travelling allowances, that the home base of a Minister shall be his principal place of residence? What is the Treasurer's principal place of residence? What was the Treasurer paid in his travelling allowance for 1986-87? If the Minister does not know, will he supply me with these details as early as possible?

—So far as the home base of the Treasurer is concerned, I have nothing to add to what the Treasurer has already told this House. As to the second part of the question regarding the yearly totals of ministerial travelling allowance, it has been the practice of this Government, not of the former Government, to release publicly the annual total payments of travelling allowance to Ministers. I have discussed this with my colleague, who is directly responsible, but of course as portfolio Minister I accept responsibility also. I have discussed with the Minister for Home Affairs the release of the 1986-87 figures. It is the Government's intention to release these figures. It has been our previous practice not only to release them but to seek verification from the Ministers and also from the office-holders of the Opposition on whether there are any significant errors in the Department of Administrative Services figures. When Senator Ray has finalised that process, the figures will be released, as they have been under this Government. Then the honourable member will be able to compare our figures with those of the Opposition Leaders. Perhaps we ought in due course to move on to see that the shadow Ministers' figures are also released.
—I direct my question to the Prime Minister and I preface it by congratulating the Government--
—When is the Prime Minister going to let you leave?

—Just hold your horses. I preface my question by congratulating the Government on the work it has done with Soviet Jewry. I am sure the Prime Minister would be aware that some four years ago approximately 12,000 to 15,000 of the black Jews of Ethiopia, popularly known as the Falashas, in what was one of the great sagas of flight from oppression, managed to escape to Israel. Many hundreds, possibly thousands, died in the gruelling march to freedom through the Sudan. Regrettably, Press and media publicity stopped this mass escape, leaving almost as many behind and the families divided. I ask the Prime Minister what action, if any, the Government has taken to place pressure on the Government of Ethiopia to allow the balance of the black Jews of Ethiopia to join their families in Israel.

—Madam Speaker, I thank the honourable member for his question without notice. I acknowledge the very deep interest and concern he has in this issue. Indeed, on a number of occasions, the honourable member has spoken with me about this matter. I am not in a position to give the honourable member a detailed answer at this point. I shall consult with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and provide the honourable member with a detailed answer.

—I have a question for the Minister for Defence. Has the Minister had drawn to his attention an advertisement in the Weekend Australian of 11 July seeking for Rockwell a commercial manager, Australian industry involvement, with responsibility for offset development, negotiating notional credits allowed for technology transfer? I repeat: `notional credits for technology transfer'. Does this reflect a fair view by some companies of this Government's attitude to valuation of technology transfer from offsets, whereby a real product outcome is forgone for technology of questionable value to Australia? If not, what action does the Government intend to take to ensure that the national interest is protected, and when can a detailed response be expected from the Government on report No. 270 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts dealing with implementation of the offsets program, which clearly identified this deficiency in assessing technology transfer valuations? Finally, does this approach of Rockwell suggest a severe shortcoming in the offset arrangements concluded for Australia's vital submarine purchase?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I must say that I have been waiting anxiously to receive a question one of these days from my opposite number, but the honourable member will do for starters. I was not aware of the particular advertisement to which the honourable member for Dundas drew my attention, but I am aware of the general points he is seeking to make through his question. I must say that from my point of view in the defence area-and this has governed the attitudes which I have sought to have the Department adopt in negotiations with the submarine contractors-we place emphasis more and more, in the contracts we sign, on Australian industry involvement as opposed to offsets. For example, on the FA18 program undertaken by our predecessors we were talking about a 30 per cent involvement in the area of offsets and Australian industry involvement. In the submarine program, in the combat systems area as distinct from the platform, which, of course, Rockwell is involved in, 45 per cent of the value of the project is in Australian industry involvement and another 15 to 20 per cent of the value of the project is in offsets. I happen to have the view that, when we are developing defence equipment projects in this country, in terms of our long term strategic requirement we do better to ensure that we have the capacity to support that equipment in-country and, whereas it is problematic whether the offsets program will provide us with that capacity to support equipment in-country, there is no doubt at all that the Australian industry involvement program will do that. I have sought to place the emphasis, as I said from the outset, in dealings with companies such as Rockwell, in dealing with the people who are producing the platform of the submarine, on increasing the quotient of Australian industry involvement.

ANSWER.PARA: It is possible for a variety of projects to be suitable for offset purposes. Some of those projects will be of a high technology variety; some others may be of a type that the honourable gentleman indicated. A value of having such a high level of Australian industry involvement now as opposed to the past is that more and more of the offsets program can, in fact, be drawn from the Australian industry involvement part of the project. This has been particularly successful in the helicopter deals that we have done recently. So an item of equipment which is useful and which counted in the project as part of the Australian industry involvement can then slot into the tender company's overall project. As a result, for example in the helicopters, parts of what is produced under the Australian industry involvement program will also be slotted into the offsets program and it will be possible to export those items of equipment to the United States of America and elsewhere where those helicopters are sold.

I do not think that this Government needs to explain to anybody its commitment to Australian industry involvement in the defence area. The Opposition simply needs to contrast its best effort, which was the FA18 program in which it managed about 30 per cent Australian involvement, to our negotiation, three or four years on, of the submarine contract where we are talking in the order of 70 per cent involvement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Speaker. Could the Minister obtain additional information to enable him to answer the question?
—The Minister has agreed to do that.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, concerns child maintenance payments. Given the Minister's commitment to the introduction of the Child Support Authority which guarantees child maintenance by the non-custodial parent, can he assure the House of the Government's intention to proceed with this project? Can he outline the timeframe for the introduction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is intending, firstly, to proceed in this session of Parliament to legislate to establish the Child Support Agency; secondly, to carry certain amendments in the family law area which have been previously announced in terms of improving the level of payment that is awarded by courts to custodial parents; and, thirdly, to make amendments in relation to the Social Security Act specifically providing for a separate income test. Providing this legislation passes through the Parliament, it is the Government's intention to have the Agency in operation as early as possible in the new year, but certainly no later than 31 March.

ANSWER.PARA: This legislation and the Government's approach in the child support area are designed to overcome very significant problems whereby two-thirds of all supporting parents effectively receive no maintenance payments. The establishment of the agency will certainly ensure that the vast majority of supporting parents will receive maintenance payments.

The creation of an independent income test is a coherent element in the Government's policy which is designed to provide positive incentives for sole parents to enter the work force. It is designed also to ensure that the Government recovers some of its very considerable expenditure in relation to sole parents. Such outlays will be increasing as a result of sole parents being made eligible for further assistance under the family package.

The Government has a determination to go ahead with this legislation. We hope that it will have the support of the Opposition and the Parliament because we believe it is a very significant reform that, on the one hand, will help to achieve our objectives in relation to child poverty and, on the other hand, will enable us to offset, I think in a very responsible and fair way, some government expenditure in relation to this group of people who, I think it is recognised, of all social security beneficiaries, tend most often to be those who are poor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support discuss with his counterpart in South Australia the report of the Bureau of Transport Economics on the closure of the Bridgewater railway line in Adelaide before that report was released? If so, what were those discussions, when did they take place and what was decided? Will the Minister explain why two copies of the report-a draft and a final report dated only one day apart-contained significant differences and why both were made public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. I did have the opportunity of having some discussions with the Minister in South Australia. My understanding of the position was that a copy of a draft of the report from the Bureau was supplied to the key parties involved in this matter, and certainly the South Australian Government, by an officer of the Bureau some time before the finalisation of the report. I have been advised by the Bureau that that draft was supplied for the purpose of checking figures which were to appear in the report relating to the position of the State Transport Authority in South Australia. The arrangement that had been made was that the South Australian Government was to be supplied with a copy of the final report before it was released to the media, including the Press; and that report was supplied to the Minister in South Australia. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to advise the House of a decision taken on 25 September 1987 by the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House in respect of the Speaker's chair. In March last year the Committee decided that the existing Speaker's chair should be transferred to the chamber of the House of Representatives in the new Parliament House as the Speaker's chair in that chamber. Since that decision was taken a good deal of work has been carried out to identify the issues involved in relocating the chair. These matters include the chair's present condition, the need for restoration after the move, practical considerations involved in its removal and relocation and the need for modifications to overcome previously recognised shortcomings. The assessment of these matters provided an opportunity to give further consideration to the appropriateness of removing the existing chair from the present chamber.

INTERJECT.PARA: This chair was a gift from the United Kingdom branch of the Empire Parliamentary Association. It is a replica of the original chair designed for the House of Commons chamber and contains timber from the Westminster Hall and from Nelson's flagship, HMS Victory. Presented in 1926, it has served as the Speaker's chair in this chamber for the whole of Parliament's occupation of this building. In doing so, the chair has become the central piece of this particular chamber, without which, I suggest, the chamber could become just another room. The design brief for the new Parliament House drew attention to the possibility that certain items might be transferred to the new building. One of these was the Speaker's chair. I have no doubt that in considering the matter last year the Joint Standing Committee made its decision to transfer the chair on the basis of tradition and the symbolic link with the Westminster Parliament.

In reviewing the decision, the Committee recognised these points; however, it also recognised the significance of preserving the integrity of the current chamber. It was felt that removal of the chair would completely destroy the character of the chamber and diminish its value as an historical testament to Australia's parliamentary development from 1927 to 1988. In this context it should be noted that in 1984 the Joint Standing Committee recommended that, after its vacation by the Parliament, this building should become a museum related to the Australian Constitution, Federation and the Commonwealth Parliament.

The new Parliament House will be a contemporary building, reflecting Australia's current traditions and values. It will incorporate a great deal of Australian skill, craftsmanship and materials. This will be particularly so in the two legislative chambers. Construction of the new building presents the opportunity for design and fabrication of a new chair in keeping with the distinctly Australian character of the new chamber.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be appreciated if those who are interjecting ceased while I am on my feet. In considering all the issues involved-that is, symbolism, tradition, the contemporary Australian parliamentary scene, the design theme of the new building and the practical issues-by a majority decision the Committee concluded that the chair should remain in the provisional Parliament House and that a new chair should be designed and fabricated for the chamber in the new Parliament House. It decided that the new chair should be made in Australia by Australian craftsmen and from Australian material.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Committee also resolved that an opportunity should be available for the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association to provide some financial contribution towards the cost of the construction of the chair, if it should so wish, as a means of maintaining its links with the House of Representatives. The Committee has requested the Parliament House Construction Authority to prepare designs for a new Speaker's chair. It is expected that the Committee will be able to consider preliminary designs at its next meeting towards the end of October.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Madam Speaker, the Opposition regrets and rejects the decision that you have just delivered on behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House.
—The chair led to the return of the Liberal Party's fortunes.

—The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade can content himself with his mindless witticisms but I think members of the Australian public have a keener sense of a certain degree of symbolism and of historical continuity in the affairs of this nation than the members of the Government apparently give them credit for. No political party, no parliament and no nation should be a total slave to tradition or to history. But any parliament which on such flimsy and insubstantial grounds rejects the most visible link that this chamber, this body of people, this body of representative Australians, has with the fountain of our parliamentary system, has insufficient regard to history and symbolism.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons advanced by you, Madam Speaker, for this decision may have satisfied a meeting of the Enmore branch of the Australian Labor Party but I do not believe that they ought to satisfy a gathering of this Parliament. As you acknowledged, the existing chair was a gift from the United Kingdom branch of the now Commonwealth Parliamentary Association in 1926. It is a replica of the original chair designed for the House of Commons that was used there until its destruction in World War II. The transfer of the present chair to the new Parliament House would represent a continuation of tradition.

Having listened to the explanation given by you, Madam Speaker, and having heard something of the discussion and debate that has gone on about this issue, I believe this is yet another example of Sir Humphrey having won a famous victory. There is no doubt that a large number of people associated with the new Parliament House are as determined as they possibly can be to destroy some of the more traditional elements of the chamber, of which the chair was the most obvious and the most visible. With great respect, Madam Speaker, your explanation is unconvincing: it gives absolutely no substantive grounds as to why the existing chair could not be moved. I suggest that it beggars both the belief and the common sense of most Australians for you to stand up and say that it is impossible in this day and age to transfer that chair some few hundred yards without doing damage to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I did not say that it was impossible. You must read the statement again.

—I am glad that you say it is not impossible, Madam Speaker. I am grateful for that guidance. In fact, in March 1986, it was not only not impossible but also eminently desirable. I say to you, with the very greatest respect, that you have not advanced one scintilla of justification or explanation as to why the decision you took in March 1986 ought to be reversed. We can only be satisfied that, amongst the members of your Committee on the Government side and amongst those who advise the Government on these matters, there is a deliberate design to break the traditional link that that chair represents.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Government members do not like it. They get very excited about this matter. I acknowledge, Madam Speaker, that in a strictly formal sense this decision is something that in the first place had to be made by the Committee, but it is something that you know-and the members of your Committee must have known-goes to the sensitivities of many people both within and outside this place about the nature of this institution. For it to be presented in a clinical fashion, as being yet another recommendation of your Committee, without any prior canvassing, in a broader sense, of the views of the parliamentary parties in this chamber-and I know that I speak for all of my colleagues on this side of the House-is something that I simply do not accept.
—Why did you block Supply?

—Your colleagues on the other side of the House can guffaw, interject and make all the little witticisms under the sun. No doubt the wisecrack machine in the court jester's office and in the office of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) will work overtime on the subject. But the reality is that in the life of any country, in the life of any parliament, a certain modicum of tradition, a certain modicum of convention, a certain modicum of symbolism, is a very important element.
—Do you remember 1975?
—Order!

—I am unconcerned by the volley of interjections. A certain modicum of symbolism is both necessary and desirable. Just as a political party, whether of the Right, the Left, the Centre Right or Centre Left, or whatever you like, has its traditions and its sensitivities, so ought a parliament. The history that this Speaker's chair has, the symbolism that it represents, the continuity that it affords in terms of the historical tradition and the antecedents of this Parliament, and its very design and nature make this particular decision quite unacceptable in the view of the Opposition. It shows an insuf- ficient balance between practicality and symbolism.

SPEECH.PARA: The last thing, Madam Speaker, with great respect, that anybody can advance, given the history of the building over the last 4 1/2 years, is a cost of several thousand dollars. Given the history of the building and the nonsense that has gone on in relation to this building over the last 4 1/2 years and the still unexplained extravagances and expenses that have occurred under the eye of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), neither you, nor anybody on the other side of the House, should start advancing expense as one of the reasons why you have taken this decision. All I can say is that, if you have taken this decision on the basis of expense, you have a remarkably selective approach to frugality, given the experiences that have gone on in relation to this building.

Madam Speaker, I find your explanation totally inadequate. You have not advanced, on behalf of the Committee, any convincing reason. It is perhaps a measure of the contempt that the majority of members of the Committee obviously feel for questions of symbolism and tradition relating to the functioning of this place. If those members do not hold that view, perhaps they will be able to indicate during the course of this discussion that that is not their view. We regard it as a totally unacceptable decision by the Committee and the Opposition rejects it. I move:

That this House rejects the recommendation of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House announced by Madam Speaker and authorises the transfer of the Speaker's chair from this House of Representatives chamber to the new Parliament in accordance with the Committee's 1986 resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second this motion. Madam Speaker, I am absolutely appalled at the effrontery of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House, of which you are Chairman, in its disregard of the symbolism of our past and the desire that I thought most members had to try to ensure that the elements of the Westminster system could be transferred to the new Parliament House. We need to understand a few things. We are about to debate the situation in Fiji. Apparently all honourable members on the other side of the House are quite prepared just to dismiss the rule of law, all of the elements of our tradition and all of those things that have anything to do with democracy and Westminster. SPEECH.PARA: Another part of the Australian Labor Party's absolutely fallacious presentation to the Australian electorate is that the Labor Party is in some way worried about our heritage. If anybody thought that Labor wanted anything to do with our heritage, we have been shown the position in true and proper perspective today. We know that it is not concerned about our history, that it is not worried about our traditions, that it wants to get rid of our flag and that it has constituted a constitutional commission to scrap the present Constitution and put in place of the Senate that has true and proper powers goodness knows what. It is very important that the people of Australia understand what this Labor Party is doing through a motion which, I understand, Madam Speaker, was initiated by your deputy. He can take little credit from it, and neither can any other honourable member who seeks to refuse the transfer of that chair to the new Parliament House.

It is important that the people of Australia have an opportunity both to see and to understand a little of the beginnings of the democratic tradition in the new Parliament House which we on this side of the House believe is sacrosanct. That chair is a symbol of those traditions. In 1986, after due and proper consideration, it was decided that that chair should be transferred to the new Parliament House. Like the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), I accept neither that cost nor difficulties of removal is an adequate excuse for the decision being made belatedly, towards the end of 1987 when we are about to move into the new Parliament House, that it suddenly cannot go there. Madam Speaker, I can assure you that the reason for moving this motion is not only that we on this side of the House reject the concept that is part of the resolution you have referred to us but also that we believe it is necessary that we continue to have in the new Parliament House all of those things from this place that are important. Madam Speaker, if you as the custodian of those values are now going to throw them aside, this place will be the poorer and your term as Speaker will be remembered not for what you have done in other areas but for the fact that you have been prepared to bow to those who seek to remove those symbols. PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Fairfax electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government has no mandate to introduce its flawed and costly ID card proposal, and that the card will not stop tax and welfare fraud and will invade the private lives of Australians.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Reject Labor's ID card proposal as the Australian public haven't given the Government a mandate to introduce it.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the `Australia Card' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth.
We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr N.A. Brown,Mr Milton and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth.

We most strongly oppose the process of `Food Irradiation' as there is a disturbing uncertainty regarding the possible health effects of this process on humans. This process has also been shown to reduce the nutritional value and affect taste, colour and texture of food, thus necessitating further unwanted additives.

We oppose the introductions of regulations that will facilitate (a) the `Food Irradiation' process by State Governments, and (b) the dumping of irradiated food products on Australia, to the detriment of our food producers.

We call on the Government to impose an immediate moratorium on all aspects of `Food Irradiation' in Australia. We urge extreme caution in processes involving radiation, where there is evidence indicating possible detrimental health effects.
We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of Cobalt-60, Caesium-137 or other radioactive substances.
And your Petitioners in duty bound, will ever pray.

We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for the possession of child pornography, and has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled-

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: -Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Government to promote new initiatives for the settlement of the Fijian crisis.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Events in Fiji move from bad to worse, and it is in these circumstances that the Opposition proposes as a definite matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to promote new initiatives for the settlement of the Fijian crisis.

From the time of the first coup in May of this year, and with the continuing crisis in Fijian democracy, the Opposition has believed that the Commonwealth should be involved. At the time of the first coup the then shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs proposed that there should be a mission to Fiji made up of Commonwealth foreign Ministers. That was not taken up. I add that had it been taken up maybe-one does not know-the foreign Ministers could have assisted in moving Fiji to some kind of a resolution of its crisis. Since the second coup we have again put two specific proposals. The first is that we should get quick Commonwealth agreement on sending to Fiji a senior and distinguished Commonwealth emissary, preferably from outside the South Pacific region, who would be seen by all parties to bring an objective appreciation to the crisis and who could assess at first hand what could be done to return Fiji to constitutional and democratic rule and make very plain to Colonel Rabuka how his actions were viewed by the Commonwealth and by the wider international community. The second proposal is to set up a small group of Commonwealth foreign Ministers to act as a means of engaging Colonel Rabuka in constructive dialogue and to work on mechanisms to assist in achieving a just and speedy political settlement of the crisis within a Commonwealth framework.

They are the proposals to which we seek a response from the Government. The Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM) is to take place in Vancouver in a few days time. While we await the Government's response we may ask this question: What is the Government's policy? Does it have something better to propose? I should like to go back to an answer given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to a question from his own side on 24 September of this year. He said:

The Government welcomes yesterday's announcement that a council of state is to be formed in Fiji, headed by the Governor-General . . . and comprising a balance of coalition and alliance members. We believe that the announcement constitutes a fundamentally important step towards a return to full parliamentary democracy in Fiji-a goal which I believe is supported by all honourable members.

Certainly, we do support that goal. Of all governments, the Australian Government should have been the best informed about events in Fiji. There is an ongoing constitutional crisis. It is a region of natural interest and influence for Australia. We have long and close ties with that country and we have major commercial investments in it. Yet at 3 o'clock on the day following the Prime Minister's answer to this House Colonel Rabuka staged his second coup. The Prime Minister failed to foresee the risk of that coup, a risk which Mr Derek Scarr, the Senior Fellow in Pacific History at the Australian National University, described as painfully misleading. He failed to see it despite the obvious and crucial need to monitor events in Fiji and despite, on one report, a warning given by Colonel Rabuka. I refer briefly to a report in the Australian newspaper of 1 October:
Australian diplomats in Suva dismissed a warning from Colonel Rabuka two weeks ago that he might mount another coup if the objectives of his May coup did not look like being achieved.

One does not know what was said. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) obviously does, but if there was even a hint of that kind of message going through it was the sort of thing that should have been considered gravely and very seriously. Yet the Prime Minister's failure and the Government's failure to assess the risk of a second coup are symptomatic of Government neglect of the South Pacific region. I remind the House of two things. First, it was three years before the Foreign Minister first visited the South Pacific. He went before to other countries such as Nicaragua and Hungary, countries which are not exactly at the centre of our interests. Second, at the time of the first coup the Foreign Minister was kept in exile overseas. When asked about this on a radio program he explained the reasons in these terms:

I should mention to you that on Tuesday night I spoke to the Prime Minister after a hijack had taken place and seemingly the situation had deteriorated. I advised him that I was taking steps to book a flight from London Tuesday night, the first available flight, to Australia.

What then happened? Senator Evans called. Senator Evans did not seem to think that it was necessary for the Foreign Minister to return. We then had a conversation between the Foreign Minister and the Prime Minister. The Foreign Minister said this:
I advised him-
that is, the Prime Minister-
that I preferred to hear that sort of advice-
that is, the advice that he had received from Senator Evans to the effect that there were no problems that required his return-

from the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister contacted me later after he returned to Canberra and said quite firmly that as both the coup and the hijack were over I should continue on the task I'd been given.

Two things can be said of that. The Prime Minister seemed to show contempt for his Foreign Minister, which he should not have. He should have had the Foreign Minister back here as soon as possible. The Prime Minister also seemed completely to misunderstand or to be ignorant of or indifferent to the gravity of the coup.

What has been Government policy since then? The Government has said that the Governor-General is the only person who will be recognised as head of state and we agree with that. That is quite right. The Government has said that it does not recognise Colonel Rabuka's actions such as his self-appointment as chief of state and the revocation of the Constitution. We agree with that. The Government has said, through the Foreign Minister and again today through the Prime Minister, that the resolution of the problem is a matter for the Fijian people. That is correct but we have an interest in the resolution of the problem and the Commonwealth has an interest in the resolution of the problem since we are dealing with a country of the Commonwealth, a country that was regarded as the showplace for democracy in the Pacific. I think the Government's attitudes can be summed up by the words `wait and see'. The Foreign Minister was recently quoted as saying that this is a classic case where patience and observation are the main virtues we have to apply. Patience is no doubt a virtue; observation is no doubt a virtue. But are we simply to remain observers? Are we simply to be patient? Do we have nothing to propose? Are we empty of ideas?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is.

—Are we to allow others to make the running? There was an interjection from a former member of the foreign service, who said that the Opposition did not have any ideas. We have put up two specific proposals. On the subject of ideas and before passing on to something else, let me remind the House as well that the Foreign Minister has said correctly, as I understand him, that the Government is not entertaining sanctions and, yet again showing patience, again observing what is taking place, the Foreign Minister and this Government allow the union movement to impose sanctions-sanctions which are stupid and unworkable and which have been shown to be unworkable in the past-and to arrogate to itself the power of determining foreign policy in this area. The Government should act against this speedily and firmly. What has happened? Nothing: patience and observation once more.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look to recent events. They have moved ominously and rapidly. The outcome of yesterday's talk between the Governor-General, Colonel Rabuka and others bodes ill. It is plain that conventional diplomacy is having little if any effect on events in Fiji. As far as we can see, conventional diplomacy is having no effect at all. It is plain that Australia by itself has no capacity to influence events in Fiji; nor, apparently, do other countries. There is no sign that anything that has been said or done by the United States, by Great Britain or by New Zealand has had any effect on the policies being pursued by Colonel Rabuka and his supporters.

What should we do? Must we not look at new measures to achieve a just and speedy resolution of the crisis and the return of the country to democratic rule? Or do we simply surrender to be observers-but observers of what? Are we to be observers of a country moving down a road towards a kind of government that I do not believe anybody in this House would support? It seems that the proposal plainly and undeniably is to entrench a minority over the whole of the inhabitants of the islands. In short, do we continue as we are or do we search for new initiatives, however difficult the situation, however bad it may presently appear and however quickly events may move?

We are not talking about imposing solutions. We are not talking about finite propositions. We are talking about constructive diplomacy. We are talking about looking at ways and means of breaking the impasse. Fiji will undoubtedly be on the agenda of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Vancouver which begins on Sunday. Honourable members will recall that at Question Time today I asked the Prime Minister this question:

Does the Prime Minister intend to propose to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM) in Vancouver next week specific measures which the Commonwealth might adopt to seek to achieve a speedy and just resolution of the Fijian crisis? If so, can he outline those measures to the House?
The answer was, in effect, no. I quote part of the Prime Minister's answer to me:
. . . there should be a statement of principle expressing the very strong view that there should be a return to the parliamentary system of democracy.
We would all agree with that. But what will a statement of principle, coming from the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, achieve? It will achieve nothing. The Prime Minister went on to say:
Should those in Fiji believe that there could be some role undertaken by the Commonwealth-
honourable members should listen to that-
I have no doubt that those attending CHOGM would be prepared to provide that.

He went on to say that, ultimately, the resolution is for the Fijians themselves. As I have said, ultimately, that is so. But what does the Prime Minister mean when he said, `Should those in Fiji believe there could be some role undertaken by the Commonwealth'? Does he have Colonel Rabuka in mind? I think not. It is perfectly absurd and it is astonishing that the Prime Minister could say, `We will, effectively, wash our hands of effective action. We will confine ourselves at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting-a unique opportunity for concerted Commonwealth action-to do two things: issue a platitudinous statement of principle and be ready to respond to any initiative from Fiji'. It would be laughable if it were not so serious.

We have an historic possibility. I say no more than that. The two proposals that the Opposition has put up merit the most serious and urgent consideration. I do not suggest that they are the only proposals that could be considered. I do not suggest that there may not be other and better ones. But they are too specific concrete proposals for how we could go about breaking the impasse and returning Fiji to parliamentary democracy, as we all want it to be. In this we should play a lead role; we should not be observers. We should not simply sit by. We should not let others make the running. We should not leave it to other countries. This is our area and an area in which we should have great influence and which is of great concern to us.

It is for us to play a lead role at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. One other thing must be said about that meeting. If the Commonwealth is to be a viable and living international entity, it must be able to provide leadership. If it cannot provide some kind of concerted action towards resolving the Fijian problem, not imposing an answer, it has reached a very sad state in its history. I do not believe that is so. I believe that with energy and determination the Government could put to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting specific proposals that may help to break the impasse, and I believe it is the Government's duty to do just that.
