TALKER.NAME: Mr HAYDEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, allow me to welcome warmly the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) on his return to Australia. I knew he was going to come to Australia in haste to save the country and the region because he released a statement on 29 September which, in the modest and so attractive way of the honourable member for North Sydney, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, John Spender, has terminated his current overseas trip because of the crisis in Fiji.

He was about to slip into his `Sir Les Spender saves the world' routine, with the crumpled hero from North Sydney arriving to the cheers of an unobservable throng of supporters. There was a real reason why he was in a hurry to come home but I do not think it had much to do with Fiji. I have no doubt that he has a genuine concern about Fiji. But, considering what he was doing overseas, and in particular allowing for the fact that he is in opposition and not in any type of executive position, Fiji is not the sort of issue on which he would have any sort of definitive influence. So what was the real reason? I suspect that it was simply that, in his short absence, a number of people behind him suddenly realised that a job opportunity was opening up. To be the shadow shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs for the Opposition had growth prospects. So, nine statements were released by seven different Opposition members on the issue of foreign affairs.

One was from the shadow shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Alexander Downer-his seat is not mentioned; his address is given just as Parliament House, which was rather discreet of him-who was fighting hard to keep a toe-hold on the issue. The honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), who is the shadow Minister for transport and aviation, no less, managed to get in on the act. How does the shadow Minister for transport and aviation manage to get in on the act? He released a statement referring to the hijacking of Australia's foreign policy. As hijacking takes place on aircraft, the shadow Minister for transport is therefore presumed to be entitled to join in on this. But the best statement was made by Senator Puplick who, in an interview, said of the Gulf imbroglio:
. . . if somebody shot Saddam Hussein the war could be over within a week.
So, the Opposition's foreign policy took on a new dimension. It believed that an assassination would resolve a difficult problem.

I really think that all this had more to do with the sudden return of the honourable member for North Sydney than did his concern about the issue of Fiji. Nothing in his speech serves to convince me otherwise. Of course, he has taken to engaging in the new initiative of word processor diplomacy. Since he has been home he has issued a number of statements on this matter. In particular, on 1 October he issued two statements. In the first statement he said that Colonel Rabuka wanted compromise and that the Commonwealth must act. Then events unfolded in the course of the day and so he put out statement No. 2, which omitted the comment that Colonel Rabuka wanted compromise and added a few other sentences. But, largely, it was a similar sort of statement. We saw from the Opposition benches the lazy man's way to be a success in foreign affairs.

In those circumstances, it is rather difficult to take the man seriously. What he has put forward here today does nothing to encourage me to change my mind on that. He has come up with a proposition, and it is a proposition which, in principle, has much merit; that is, that there should be Commonwealth agreement to send a senior emissary to Fiji to test the water, as it were; that this should be followed up by a visit by a group of Commonwealth Ministers; and that these Commonwealth Ministers, in a small group, should engage Colonel Rabuka in constructive dialogue. In principle the idea has much merit. But in practice how relevant is it? If we thought there was some prospect of being able to put those sorts of propositions into operation, it would have been done well before now. The fact is that, if those sorts of initiatives are to be undertaken, there must be a mood that accepts them; there must be an atmosphere which is receptive to the proposal. In particular, the main players-not just one, not just Colonel Rabuka, but the Governor-General and others-have to be of an inclination to respond positively to these proposals.

One of the things that one learns as Foreign Minister in handling foreign policy, in working with professional diplomats, in dealing with other countries, in protecting the interests of one's own country and in looking after concerns in the region-all of these things come together in this case-is that one cannot engage in a public dialogue on all the detail of what one is doing. One cannot outline various propositions that are being explored or lay down the next set of steps which could be initiated if current conditions were to go in a direction which was not regarded as terribly helpful.

In stating this, of course, I must emphasise that the situation in Fiji is taking place within the sovereign territory of the nation of Fiji. It is, in the end, fundamentally an issue for the Fijians to fix up. It is, as was correctly pointed out by the honourable member for North Sydney, an issue in which Australia and a number of other countries have important national interests because it arises in our region. There could be various forms of consequences in the region if the situation were to deteriorate in some quite undesirable way. I acknowledge all of those things. But we do not conduct our diplomacy publicly-at least, not in all respects in which we are engaged in it. Because I have said publicly that it is preferable to be patient and to observe does not mean-and the implication certainly cannot be justified-that the Government is doing nothing but that. We are extremely active in regard to Fiji. We are in frequent contact with Colonel Rabuka. We do the best we can to shore up confidence in and support for the role of the Governor-General. We see him as critical, as things now stand, to any chance for a successful resolution of the issues in Fiji.

It would be counterproductive for me to detail what we might try to encourage and what we might try to influence in a subtle and helpful way. The best thing we can do right now is not to be strident and not to convey the impression that we wish to interfere in the affairs of Fiji. At present the relationships there are at a delicate stage. People need room to move, if they are going to move. Maybe they will not move or maybe, if they do move, the final movement might not be in a direction that we care it should occur. If we start to lay down prescriptions and become querulous or strident about it and, more particularly, if we seem to be paternalistic about it, it will be totally counterproductive.

The honourable member for North Sydney made quite a number of points. Essentially, the concrete things that he came up with were those two propositions about Commonwealth agreement. I say this to the honourable member: we are in regular contact with the Commonwealth Secretariat, the British High Commissioner in Fiji, our New Zealand colleagues and other colleagues such as the United States. We are in contact with London and we have spoken to some Commonwealth countries about this concern that we share generally. If the two propositions that the honourable member has put forward are practical propositions and are appropriate for implementation, that time has not yet arrived--

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you raise them at CHOGM?

—Let me finish. That time has not arrived either in fact, in the circumstances that we see in Fiji at present, or in terms of the evaluation of people with whom we have been talking. Quite clearly, there is much to commend a constructive and serious exploration of possible roles for the Commonwealth at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that today-if the people of Fiji are prepared to accept that role. I stress that, if they are not prepared to accept it, we cannot impose it on them. We could seek to persuade them to see that there are certain roles which could be undertaken, but we cannot impose it on them. Once we try to do that, we will certainly be going down a road which will be disastrous in terms of any pretence we might try to lodge towards influencing the unfolding of events in that country.

SPEECH.PARA: I take up a few other points that the honourable member made. I appreciated his phone call the other day in which he said that he believed the Government was acting in a way which was appropriate in the circumstances. Putting to one side some of my earlier provocative, puckish but friendly comments, I reciprocate by saying that the comments he put forward today were designed-putting to one side the politics, of which there was not unexpectedly a little-to be constructive. But it is wrong of him to say that there is something seriously defective in our understanding of what is going on in the south west Pacific or in Fiji, particularly in regard to this issue.

We cannot claim to have an absolute and perfect knowledge of events that are about to unfold in that country or, indeed, in any other country. It is true that we were not aware that the second coup would occur at the point at which it did. But we were aware that Colonel Rabuka had said to the Great Council of Chiefs, for instance, that, if things did not sort themselves out in the way in which he believed they should, he might have to act to clean up the situation. He mentioned that to our High Commissioner at a function. He did not say that he would call another coup. He said that he might have to take action to tidy it up, clean it up, or whatever the exact formulation was. We were watching events to see what might happen.

The Governor-General knew of these comments; the Great Council of Chiefs knew of these comments; other leading players knew of these comments. They live there; they are Fijians. They are involved in what outwardly seems to be a very simple and uncomplicated society, but which in fact is hierarchically structured, very complex and, at various levels of that society, quite secretive about what is going on. The Governor-General did not know that there would be a coup; nor did the majority of the Great Council of Chiefs; nor did many other people; nor did any representative of any other mission in Fiji.

I shall not waste time going over the comment that we have neglected the South Pacific, except to mention that I have visited more of the countries-all of the countries except one, in fact-of the Pacific Forum than any other Foreign Minister. I am the only Foreign Minister to have undertaken a comprehensive visit to those countries and to do so officially, not as a resting point on the way from North America to Australia, nor as part of some obligation such as an independence celebration or something of that nature. I invite the honourable member for North Sydney to undertake similar visits to that part of the world. I invite him to do so quite soon. I invite all honourable members to take an active interest in visiting that part of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I trust you also believe that the Government should pay for it.
—The honourable member wants the Government to pay for it. An allowance is provided to him.
—I have just about spent that, as you could well understand.

—I checked the other day and he has not yet made a claim on his allowance. The honourable member has not made a claim. He has to submit an application with an outline of his proposed study program, and he has not yet done that. He has not indicated where he might want to go. I invite him to spend the money by visiting this important part of the world because that is why we introduced this benefit for honourable members like him. It is much more important for him to go than for other back bench members of his Party to go.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member was quite wrong when he said that no country, no one, has any influence and hence new initiatives are necessary. I believe that countries are able to exercise a degree of influence from time to time but how much influence they are able to exercise is hard to measure. At this stage my feeling is-perhaps the honourable member could have said it better-that not a lot of influence can be exerted by us, the United States of America or other countries. But some countries have the potential to improve that influence by persisting with the line which has generally been agreed on by countries which have representation on the ground in Fiji, by seeking influence, by seeking low key operations and working separately or collectively as the circumstances warrant.

One person who has had quite an impact on Fiji is the Queen. I have been quite impressed by the extraordinary impact that the Queen has had by her firm statements about what is happening in Fiji and statements about how concerned she is. She certainly reinforced the position of the Governor-General. I can assure the honourable member--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I get the impression from listening to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), and following the course of Australia's response to the events in Fiji, that the Australian Government and, in particular, the Foreign Minister have been caught like a kangaroo on the road in the headlights of an oncoming car. They have stood there startled, unprepared and unaware of what to do next. From the long discourse of the Foreign Minister this afternoon, we are still none the wiser as to what the Government's thinking is on future events in Fiji and what further responses might be practicable. That is not surprising coming from a government which has conducted Australia's relations with the South Pacific in such a way that that relationship, in general terms, has become one of the unsung disasters of the 4 1/2 years of the Hawke Government. In all of those 4 1/2 years the Opposition has repeatedly warned the Government that it must pay closer attention to matters in the Pacific.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard speeches from the honourable member from Kooyong (Mr Peacock) when he was the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, speeches from the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) when he had that role, speeches from the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) and even from me repeatedly emphasising that the Government must pay closer attention to matters in the South Pacific. These speeches may have gone unreported-that is one thing-but, more seriously, they have gone unheeded by a government which, apparently, is more interested in visits to Central America and other parts of the world and issues pertaining to Central America and other parts of the world than it is in our region. It is not surprising that, after 4 1/2 years of complete inactivity in our region, the Government professes great surprise about what has happened in Fiji.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs claims that he has made visits to the Pacific. He has made one visit to a number of South Pacific countries in the 4 1/2 years he has been Foreign Minister. I point out to the House that he has also made one visit to Central America in that time. In 1986 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) refused to go to the South Pacific Forum. It was not sufficiently important for him to attend; he sent his Deputy instead.

The Government, throughout its terms in office, has repeatedly cut back on its aid budget for the South Pacific. Again there is a very substantial decline in real terms in aid for the South Pacific in the 1987-88 Budget and this comes at a time when the Government has just given tax deductible status for donations which assist Nicaragua. The Government has a curious sense of priorities there. I will not go into the details but, in addition, our relationship with France in the region could be described only as chaotic. When this Government came to power one of its early regional initiatives was to abandon the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meetings which had been so painstakingly put together by the Fraser Government. We should not have been surprised by this because, on 7 June 1979, the now Foreign Minister said of the Commonwealth to the House of Representatives:
. . . I am far from being a glowing approbater-
that is a new word; I suppose it means somebody who approves-
of the concept of the Commonwealth of Nations and Commonwealth heads of government these days.

In other words, the Foreign Minister has never looked kindly on the Commonwealth and that is one of the reasons why the Government quite happily wound up the Commonwealth heads of government regional meetings. The only initiative in the Pacific we have had from this Government is the establishment of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, an initiative which has simply weakened the role of our allies in the region and done nothing to strengthen our role in the region, the role of the United States in the region and the security of the region in the interests of future generations of Australians. It is against that important background that this Government has found itself confronted with a coup in Fiji.

Let me look at the Government's initial response to the 14 May coup. This Government was characteristically negligent. The Foreign Minister was, by coincidence, in New York I think at the time-perhaps he could not have helped that-but he would not come back to Australia and the reason he would not come back was that the Prime Minister rang him and asked him not to come back.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said, `Leave it to me, Bill'.

—Indeed he said, `Leave it to me, Bill' and when the Foreign Minister eventually returned to Australia well after the coup had taken place, he was mightily unhappy with the way the Prime Minister had conducted Australia's response to that coup. Regarding the second coup, the Government has clearly ignored the warnings that the Foreign Minister admitted this afternoon it had received from the Australian High Commission in Suva. According to a report in the Australian, to which the honourable member for North Sydney referred and the Minister for Foreign Affairs admitted existed, the High Commissioner had cabled Australia a week or so before the coup took place warning that it could take place. Yet when the coup took place the Government was amazed. It claimed that it had never predicted that such a thing would happen. It claimed that it had no intelligence whatsoever and that it could not be expected that Australia have intelligence that such a coup was going to take place. We discovered that that information was incorrect and that the charges of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) that Australia's intelligence seemed to be ineffective were correct because the Government was not responding to the advice that it was receiving from its High Commission in Suva. The Government stands condemned for its negligence in that respect.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to compare the details of the way the Government has responded to the coups. After the first coup the Prime Minister, who took charge of affairs on that occasion, attacked the whole of the Fijian nation with a series of abusive statements but he gave no constructive alternative solutions. The Government came up with nothing constructive. Understandably, it was concerned-we supported this concern-about the demise of democracy in that country. No member on this side of the House or, for that matter doubtless, on the other side of the House would ever condone power being gained through the barrel of a gun. But the Government did nothing after the first coup and that has been the critical period.

After the second coup the Foreign Minister, rightly, immediately flew back to Australia but the response of the Government was, once more, fairly unimaginative and, in the view of the Opposition, it lacked leadership. We have supported some of the Government's responses. Obviously, we support its condemnation of the coup. We have supported the Government's decision not to recognise Colonel Rabuka or any emissaries of Colonel Rabuka, and that is correct. We have supported the termination of the defence co-operation agreement and we have also supported the Government's decision not to impose any official sanctions. However, we have not supported the Government's decision to cut off altogether aid to Fiji because if we cut off aid-just as occurs when we impose economic sanctions-we would be striking at the livelihoods of ordinary Fijians. We would not be striking at the coup leaders and the military who have imposed the coup.

We continue to provide aid to Nicaragua and we continue to provide aid to Vietnam but it suits us at the moment to cut out aid to Fiji. It is a curious situation and what the Government is doing in taking that decision is leaving a vacuum which can inevitably be filled by other people. There have been some reports, which may or may not be justified, of the representative of Libya in Rome saying that Libya will fill any vacuums in the aid vote created by Western countries withdrawing their aid to Fiji. Whether or not that is to happen, whether that report is alarmist or whether it is accurate-and it may well be alarmist-the simple fact is that it points to the danger of a vacuum being created and that vacuum being filled. But our objection is a more deeply humanitarian objection than that. Our objection is that the Government is striking at the livelihoods of ordinary Fijians rather than striking at the people who have been responsible for imposing the illegal coup. We have said again and again that we oppose the decision of the Government to sit on its hands and not act against the self-imposed boycott of Fiji by the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia. The Government says no to official sanctions but it does nothing about trade union sanctions which are de facto sanctions against Fiji. Yet, that sort of imposition by the Waterside Workers Federation is clearly illegal under section 30k of the Crimes Act and is of doubtful legality under section 45d of the Trade Practices Act. Ultimately what the Government has failed to do is come forward with the sorts of constructive init- iatives that have been proffered by the honourable member for North Sydney and me when I was the acting shadow Minister. We have heard nothing from the Government about whether it has put forward those initiatives to our Commonwealth partners or to the Commonwealth Secretary-General. All we have heard from the Government is that it will be thinking about these things. It has been negligent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The kind of windy rhetoric we have just heard from the Opposition benches masks the fact that the Opposition fundamentally agrees with the course the Government, and specifically the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), has taken in handling developments in Fiji. It is perfectly right, as the Foreign Minister pointed out earlier, that the Opposition has issued a great number of statements in the absence abroad during these events of the nominal Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs matters. I looked at those before entering the debate just to see the extent of agreement. It was very difficult for me because the terms of the matter of public importance are:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to promote new init- iatives for the settlement of the Fijian crisis.

It is very difficult for me to see, and it is even more difficult after this debate to discern, what those new initiatives are and on what matters the Opposition disagrees with the Government. I am looking at the transcript of an interview with the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), the acting Opposition foreign affairs spokesman, on 29 September. A number of questions were put to him. The first question was:
You object to the cutting off of foreign aid?
He answered:
Yes of course we support many of the measures that the Government has taken against this illegal coup but we do object to the cutting off of foreign aid for a variety of reasons.

To deal with that point first: the honourable member for Mayo-in what I sense was a reversal of position-said that he thought the cutting off of foreign aid is in fact not a good idea. What the Australian Government has done is to cut off military aid and defence co-operation aid to the Government of Fiji. That is a very clear demonstration of disapproval to the people who organised this coup. It has not cut off civil aid. Indeed, it has made it specifically clear that those students from Fiji who are studying in Australia will continue to be supported. They are engaged in courses which will ultimately result in the betterment of ordinary Fijians. So, in that respect we have done precisely what the Opposition thinks we should be doing. The second point of agreement was demonstrated when the interviewer asked the honourable member for Mayo:
Would you recall the defence advisers?
The honourable member said:
Yes we would. We certainly support the measures the Government's taken in relation to defence co-operation with Fiji. We strongly support those measures.
He went on to say:

. . . the Government has done precisely the right thing there. I think in diplomatic terms it has done the right thing by saying it wouldn't recognise any new Government established by Colonel Rabuka and that it will not accept any diplomatic representative from Fiji who is a representative of Colonel Rabuka.
The Opposition is unable to find any point of disagreement with the way we have handled the diplomatic aspects of the crisis. The interviewer went on to ask:
And of course that means you would be unwilling to recognise the new Fijian High Commissioner to Australia?
The honourable member for Mayo said:
We'd agree with the Government on that.

So, I discern very little in what the sorcerer's apprentice had to say while the sorcerer was away, by way of disagreement with the way the Government has handled the crisis. Indeed, I return to the earlier coup in Fiji when the Australian Government was extremely active in trying to bring about some kind of resolution, some kind of peaceful settlement. No one from the Opposition benches has bothered to recall that at that time the South Pacific Forum agreed that a delegation should be sent to Fiji-provided members of it were not going to have their heads shot off by those in authority in Fiji-to try to arrive at some compromise. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Foreign Minister were leading participants in setting the groundwork for that agreement by the South Pacific Forum. It did not come off because, something we have now become accustomed to, the parties in Fiji were too pigheaded to allow it to go ahead.

There are further points of agreement. The Opposition agrees with us that we should continue to regard the Governor-General as the sole constitutional authority in Fiji and that our actions should conduce to shoring up his authority. That is precisely what we have been doing. The Opposition agrees that sanctions are not a helpful way of attempting to resolve this crisis. The Opposition agrees with us that a resolution of the matter ultimately has to be for Fijians themselves. So, it is with a sense of disappointment that one looks at these new initiatives that the Opposition feels ought to be taken. I listened carefully to what the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) had to say. He said, `The Opposition has no finite proposals'. I say amen to that. The proposals appear to boil down to what this Government did in relation to the last coup in Fiji; that is, to organise senior emissaries followed by a small group of Ministers to engage Colonel Rabuka in dialogue, much the same as our response, although rather better orchestrated, last time, and to bring up some form of proposals at the Vancouver meeting of the Commonwealth Heads of Government. I see very little disagreement because, as the Prime Minister made clear in answer to a question today, thought is being given to what would be an appropriate response by the Commonwealth Heads of Government, and you can bet your bottom dollar that something of a constructive kind will come out of that.

In quoting what the shadow Foreign Minister and the acting shadow Foreign Minister had to say, I suspect we do not exhaust the range of views in the Opposition about what should be done because that well-known and popular spokesman for the Opposition, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, has uttered a somewhat different view. I notice in a report in the Age that he is quoted as supporting the coup. He says:
I am sure that Colonel Rabuka has the support of the bulk of the people there in Fiji. They are very strongly on his side.

Talk about the bull in the china shop! This must reflect a good part of what the people in the Opposition think. They are rather attracted to jackboots riding roughshod over democracy-they do their share of it themselves-and they are attracted to men on horseback who exert their authority. I regard that intervention by Sir Joh as exceedingly unhelpful, something that cannot help but complicate the way in which this very delicate crisis is being handled. I believe the Australian people have welcomed and supported the way in which the Foreign Minister and the Prime Minister have handled this series of events in an area close to us and of great importance to us. Having read all that the Opposition has had to say and all that it has had to suggest on this question, I think: better the Foreign Minister handling this than all the Opposition members put together. What has he done of a constructive kind? The first thing is that he said we must keep calm, we must be patient and observe what is going on. That seems to me the essence of sound sense-that we should monitor the situation and arrive at a response that is likely to be helpful in a quiet sort of way, and that is not done by making statements through the newspapers. Secondly, we have engaged in the most thorough and active protection of Australians and the interests of Australians. I did not hear a word about that from members of the Opposition. I do not suggest that that is because they would not support the Government in the stance it has taken, but it shows a certain poverty of spirit that they do not acknowledge that the Government has been exceedingly active in protecting the interests of Australians resident in Fiji, of whom there are large numbers, Australians who do business there, Australians who visit Fiji for purposes of tourism, and journalists who go there. It seems to me to have been handled in an excellent way by the Minister that we should support actively the position of the Governor-General and his role in a peaceful solution, that we should avoid heavy-handed interference and that we should develop a position for Vancouver. The Fijians have to resolve this situation. The way in which the Australian Government is assisting that resolution has been entirely proper, and it is disappointing that there should be such poverty of constructive suggestions from the Opposition as to how we might better do that.

If one endangers national security, makes misleading statements on Customs forms, fails to submit a tax return or declares an interest in Cabinet, misleads the Parliament on contractual arrangements for coastal surveillance, or brings the Government into disrepute by lack of attention to legislative detail in the ID card legislation or, as we learned today, if one happens to produce one day after a draft report a report from a technical body for which one is responsible, which happens to come to entirely different conclusions, it does not matter. This is a government which really fears the truth above all. The facade of ministerial propriety is much more important to it than the reality. The capital offence in the Hawke Government is telling the truth. Last year Senator Ryan told the truth about home interest rates. Honourable members will remember she was carpeted and then given responsibility for all the jobs no one else wanted in this year's ministerial reshuffle. In the House the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support (Mr Duncan) told us the truth-or we think so-or at least part of it. He was carpeted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), but his career has been temporarily secured because, like all of those who are members of the Labor Ministry, it is based not on ability, not on what is good for Australia, but on a factional deal.

Meanwhile, off-stage left, before an audience of Labor lawyers, we have had the much more important Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who has also been telling the truth. He wore a deeper hole in the well-worn prime ministerial carpet, but the truth he told is too important to be hidden. It is nothing less than an admission, by one of the two senior Ministers whose names appear on the front of the Budget Papers. They state:
Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88
Budget Statements 1987-88. Circulated by the Honourable P. J. Keating, MP, Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia and Senator the Honourable Peter Walsh Minister for Finance . . .

Senator Walsh was one of those people who subscribed to those Papers. Had I time I would go through in detail some of those comments. But he is the one who has really blown the top off the Treasurer's Budget Speech. He has contributed nothing less than the admission that the policy on which the nation has been guided by the Treasurer and by the Prime Minister and its keystone-of course the Budget-are on the wrong track. It is nothing less than a complete vindication of the Opposition's concerns about Government complacency in the face of Australia's very serious underlying economic position. And it is nothing less than a condemnation of the efforts of the Government-especially those of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer-to hide that truth from Australians. On 16 September the Treasurer was hailed as a financial Apollo-at least by a few financial journalists. Today he is revealed as nothing more than a modern Icarus, whose flimsy wings have melted in the heat of the truth.

Just consider these quotes from what we all know were Senator Walsh's carefully considered comments: `Australia is certainly not out of trouble', he said. `I'm a bit worried that the Budget might be oversold', he said. `Certainly, if there was another commodity price slide, the International Monetary Fund will be knocking on the door again', Senator Walsh said. `I can give you', and here Senator Walsh was speaking anecdotally, in that famous phrase, `a list of 200'-expletive deleted-`programs off the top of my head that can't be justified by social justice, equity or economic efficiency grounds, and the reason we haven't abandoned them is because we don't have the political courage to do so'.

Honourable members will remember the Treasurer's petty response to that. `All that Senator Walsh was doing', he said, `was giving us a run again on his long run views on certain expenditure programs, views which have been broadly rejected in the Expenditure Review Committee over eight sessions'. What a condemnation of the Expenditure Review Committee.

If honourable members look at the Budget, there is little doubt that if criticism of the new areas, new pockets of poverty in the middle-income group, are added to those 200 expletive deleted programs that cannot be justified by social justice, equity or economic efficiency grounds, they will see that neither on the basis of social justice nor on the basis of economic management has the Australian Labor Party succeeded in the Budget. But most damaging of all have been the comments of Senator Walsh that Australia has been a lucky country for a long time. It is not so lucky any more, and if we do not challenge most of the absurd notions the majority of Australians have about what they are entitled to and what is essential to them and what is not, then we are going down the Argentinean road.

It is not only Senator Walsh who has told us since the Budget that the Government should have followed a different stratagem; we have now learned there is a third view of the economic management of Australia according to Ministers of the Hawke Government.

We all need to remember that the third version of the gospel comes from no less a person than the Leader of the Government in the Senate, who is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button. All honourable members will remember that he said only a few days ago, `For a variety of fundamental reasons I still think the Australian dollar won't go higher than it is now. From an industry point of view I would prefer the Australian dollar to be around US65c to US68c and I hope that it will follow in the next few months'. People need to understand that from the point of view of those of us involved in export industries we could not agree with him more that if the dollar were lower those whom we represent would be able to get more for their product.

We have to remember that this third version of economic management in Australia immediately caused a drop of 2c in the value of the Australian dollar on the money markets. It then managed to generate what I think we all thought was rather an interesting comment from the Treasurer in the Age on Monday, 5 October. When speaking of Senator Button, he said, `The only utterances on the exchange rate you ought to be concerned with are those from myself and the Prime Minister. We control monetary policy'. His remarks followed those of Senator Button and, while the Treasurer declined to comment on the dollar's value, we need to remember that we now have three ways by which the economy should be run. We have the Treasurer saying, `Everything in the garden is lovely. Never mind that we had a fortuitous increase in income. We did not cut spending. We came out with a figure that I want you all to believe'. The Government really said there is a $27m deficit--

SPEECH.PARA: Only a few weeks after the introduction of the Budget, we have three versions-that of the Treasurer, that of Senator Walsh, and that of Senator Button. I wish to goodness that somewhere along the way they would realise that the Opposition worries about the economy from the point of view of the average citizen. As the National Party of Australia sees the position, the Treasurer had the chance in the 1987 Budget to begin atoning for his failures in the previous four Budgets. With a significant majority for the Government and with three years of its term to run, the Treasurer could have, and should have, taken the type of action which Senator Walsh urged. Instead, the Treasurer squibbed it, just as he did at the Tax Summit or after his `banana republic' remark. The bovver boy of the New South Wales Right talks tough but cannot hack it in the rucks.

Instead of the tough spending cuts demanded by our grave current account deficit, instead of the cuts in tax demanded by the need to boost effort, incentive and investment, we have a Budget built on complacency and self-deception. The complacency has been exposed by the Minister for Finance. The deception lies in the claim that the Budget is balanced-a claim designed to dazzle financial markets. The Treasurer is abroad, pleading with overseas investors to invest in this country simply so that our credit rating will not be reduced further. I shall say something more about that in a moment, but the claim has also been designed to dazzle the media. That deception has been clearly exposed in the debate in this chamber since the presentation of the Budget.

The balanced Budget rests on creative book-cooking-a combination of tax increases, asset sales and one-off revenue increases. The Government's position on asset sales is that of a household, unable to pay its food bills, which decides to raise money by selling the crockery. Of course, one can pretend to balance a budget in that way. But for how long? The crockery will not last indefinitely. It is all rather like the Treasurer's tax return or his continuing travel allowance, which the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) asked about today. It is not what should be done that the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) does; far from it-it is what he can get away with. The crunch has to come, as it must, when he pretends to balance the Budget by including one-off Reserve Bank profits, windfall Mint sales of gold coins and $1 billion of asset sales.

Tax is the third element of the Government's creative book-cooking. This year taxes will increase by $5.5 billion. Of that increase, $3 billion will fall on individuals. What I want to say to the Treasurer and the Government is that many ordinary Australians are finding life very tough. The Government must understand that the paper shuffling, which for this Government passes for a reasonably affluent society, is not the way in which ordinary households balance their budgets. Even the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have admitted that the surge in tax revenue was such that they did not know the final outcome until a few days before the presentation of the Budget.

This Budget continues the deception that tax reform under Labor has benefited ordinary taxpayers. In fact, there are significant real increases in provisional tax, company tax, fringe benefits tax-which will increase by 33 per cent this year-and sales tax, and an overall tax increase of about 1.5 per cent in real terms. That is the price that ordinary Australians are paying for a government that is spending money without any concept of eliminating the programs to which Senator Walsh referred. It is true there has been a welcome change of heart on negative gearing, but how that change of heart conflicts with the pre-election rhetoric of the Treasurer and with the off-the-cuff response he made to retail sales figures! The Treasurer's friend, New South Wales Premier Unsworth, said, `I think it might be helpful if you could do something to try to interrupt the market flow. There have been a few property sales that we are concerned about'. Instead of doing things on a proper basis, the Treasurer, in an off-the-cuff response, has intervened to prevent property sales to overseas purchasers, in circumstances that one must suspect. It is only the appalling rise in home rentals in Sydney that has forced the change of heart.

The Budget includes a collection of sleight-of-hand measures, apart from taxation, which go right to the credibility of the Treasurer. First, there is the claim that $1 billion of domestic debt and $1 billion of overseas debt are to be repaid. That would be commendable, if it were true. To repay that existing debt, the Government would be borrowing new funds. It would be robbing Peter to pay Paul, if honourable members will pardon the pun. Genuine debt reduction can occur only with a Budget in surplus. Then there is the claim that the Government will reduce the size of the Public Service by more than 3,000. Again, that would be very commendable, if it were true. But what Australians have not been told is that all the Government's new measures-the family program and the identity card, among others-will need about 3,000 additional public servants to administer. I am fascinated to know whether the additional public servants-almost 2,000 of them-who were to be put on to handle the Australia Card will still be employed. Knowing the way this Government operates, I have little doubt that those additional public servants will be employed, irrespective of whether an identity card is introduced, because the Government does not seem to understand that part of its difficulties lies in the public sector. As far as pubic servants are concerned, the net loss from those figures is next to nothing. This is the kind of thimble and pea trickery that the Treasurer hoped would be obscured by the dazzle of the so-called balanced Budget.

The Budget might have been seen superficially as one that was good for the paper shufflers, but for ordinary Australians it does nothing. The Treasurer was given a chance at the beginning of a new parliament. Whether or not he has acted in this way because of his leadership aspirations, one can only conjecture, but this Budget shows he has missed his chance. Even its forecasts are bleak: unemployment `flat'; a slight moderation in wage and inflation growth, but still well out of line with our competitors; very low real growth in investment; and a one per cent fall in the output of the rural sector. Speaking for the rural sector, I can say that many Australians are trying to work out whether they will be able to survive this year with the measures taken by the New South Wales Government on borrowings. With increased interest rates on home mortgages, it is almost impossible for the ordinary home owner, not just those in the rural sector, to survive.

Above all, no major improvement is forecast in what Senator Walsh has rightly identified as our fundamental problem-the current account deficit. Even the expected improvement depends on some brave assumptions about low import growth. It is a Budget based on hope, not on realism. As another example, there is nothing in the Budget to recognise the enormous problems Australia faces within a few years, with declining domestic oil production producing a huge import bill-as high as $3 billion-by the early 1990s. The implications of that for our present chronic current account deficit are obvious, yet the Government has made it clear that it will continue with a resources rent tax, cash bonus bidding for oil exploration areas and a capital gains tax regime which severely hinders effective oil exploration policies.

There is nothing in this Budget which recognises the sham of Labor's uranium policy-now admitted even by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). That policy, which makes scientific history by isolating `good' and `bad' uranium and which prevents the proper development of Australia's uranium resources for the world's growing electricity generation needs, also denies Australia valuable export income. But this Budget is stymied by the Government's continuing refusal to accept the need to abandon that stupid policy. There is nothing in this Budget to encourage productive investment. The restoration of negative gearing on real estate may be welcome, but the delay in rectifying the mistaken ban on this measure has cost home renters dearly.

There is nothing in the Budget to encourage small business, to restore incentive and reward for effort. There is nothing to support the rural sector, which together with mining remains the backbone of our export economy. The sooner the Government realises that our traditional exports must be encouraged the sooner we will have a chance to get out of the difficult circumstances we are now in. Instead, there is a broken promise on wool research funding and the virtual abolition, after a long decline under Labor, of fuel freight equalisation at major cost to Australians living and working in remote and isolated areas.

The clear message of this Budget is that the Government is going to be forced, either in a mini-Budget early next year or in next year's Budget, to take the action it has put off taking this year. That delay is likely to be costly. Because he squibbed the chance this year, the Treasurer will have to bite deeper next year, if he finds the determination to attack our fundamental economic problems-and I stress the word `if'. In the meantime our problems grow. The damaging effects of the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax on incentive and investment will continue. People need to remember that those taxes are part of the reason why the Treasurer presents this fraud of a Budget to us. The National Party opposed both these taxes from the start and our position has not changed. Until there is genuine tax reform-and by that we mean a reduction in the total tax burden paid by the individual and therefore in government spending-there can be no real potential for economic growth in this country.

I have already said that the problems lie in the fallacious presentation of the Budget. It means fewer jobs for our children, a weaker productive sector, a less competitive economy, less money to fight real inequities in our society, a weaker defence force with fewer service men and women, higher taxes, new pockets of poverty and no redress of the fundamental macro-economic problems the Treasurer's blinkered vision ignores. That is the legacy of this Budget. It will remain long after the Budget itself is forgotten.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard what must be the most intellectually bankrupt response from a major leader of a party to a Budget in the seven years that I have been in this House. How intellectually bankrupt it was will come out in the context of my speech, because not only was there absolutely nothing new in it, but also one would think that there had not been an election, that the Australian people had not approved certain courses of action, that the people had not rejected some of the formulas which the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) has put forward here today. All we have had from him is the mouthing of the New Right, the continuing attempt to implement the philosophy and approach of the New Right-the very approach which was put to the Australian people in the last election only two months ago and decisively rejected by them. Besides the formulas of the New Right, the only thing that the Leader of the National Party had going for him, so to speak, was to quote from comments supposedly made by Senator Walsh. I will have something to say both in relation to the attack on the Budget by the New Right and the comments of Senator Walsh. In the first part of my speech I want to reply to the arguments and claims that have been made on the Budget from this perspective. This is not to deny that there are some weaknesses in the Budget and some alternative ways of dealing with the central questions of the current account deficit. I will be making some suggestions in relation to this in the second part of my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me begin by stating that the claims made by the Leader of the National Party and Senator Walsh that the Budget is in fact in deficit are quite mistaken and misleading. On the contrary, it could be argued that the Budget is more than balanced, that it is, in fact, substantially in surplus. It should be remembered that the overall figures in relation to the deficit relate to both the domestic and foreign components. But many economists would argue that if we are looking at the Australian economy and its chances for growth and productive investment in the future, the key variable is not the overall Budget deficit but the domestic Budget deficit. When one looks at the domestic Budget one sees that it is not in deficit but that there is a massive surplus to the tune of $3.7 billion. As a consequence, it is clear that the Budget is decidedly contractionary in nature.

I would like to remind the Opposition parties and Senator Walsh that this significant contraction of the economy has been achieved primarily by the winding back of public sector services. In 1986-87, 1987-88 and 1988-89, the Government has seen fit to withdraw funds from every major category of Budget outlays. We should remember that in broad macroeconomic terms this Budget alone will achieve a net withdrawal of government funds to the tune of $2.5 billion in both 1987-88 and 1988-89. So much for the comments of the Leader of the National Party who clearly does not know what he is talking about when he says that there have been no reductions. Of course, this does not take into account the asset sales. I believe that now the Budget is in balance and the domestic Budget is showing a very large surplus, we should strongly oppose any further reductions in public services. The simple fact of the matter is that Senator Walsh was wrong and should not have made those comments. The cutbacks that have already occurred have imposed burdens on the community as a whole and, in some cases, disproportionate burdens on certain individuals.

For example, as a result of the May mini-statement savings, a large proportion of the widow's pension was eliminated from the Australian social security system. This pension, brought in by a Labor government decades ago, has become part of the expectation of women in Australia; should they become widowed, they know they will be looked after. Suddenly, since May, women who had not yet turned 45 years of age as at 14 July 1987 and who no longer had care of children under the age of 16, have been required to register as unemployed and undergo the rigours of the scrutiny of the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security offices before they are granted income assistance. Many of these women are working class people who, since the unfortunate deaths of their husbands, have spent many years bringing up their children with the expectation that they would be receiving the widow's pension indefinitely. Suddenly, they are thrown on to the heap of the unemployed, in many cases with no experience of paid work and little hope of coping without training and work skills. This is just one example of how cost-cutting decisions can create substantial human suffering. It is not an abstract exercise. It is something which has a direct effect on people.

Another area is child care, and I must say that I particularly object to Senator Walsh's attack on publicly provided child care and his insistence that it should be cut. Child care is an important social need and we should be looking at expanding both the number of places available in child care and its forms. The Federal Government has in the last three years scrutinised its expenditures and eliminated waste and duplication. More cuts in the provision of services will have dangerous social implications for our country. Further reductions in services not only will result in many poor people being unable to gain reasonable opportunities in life, but also will reduce the quality of life for us all. This is because non-welfare services such as the provision of culture and the protection of the environment are generally not provided by the private sector and need to be provided through the public sector.

The Australian people in the recent election decisively rejected the ideas of the New Right in relation to the dismantling of public services, even though they were being bribed by promises of tax cuts. It is now time to accept the judgment of the people and stop these incessant attacks on the Australian public sector and the services which it provides. I am very pleased that the Government has moved away from the philosophy of cuts in the September Budget and has, in fact, begun the process of redistribution through the introduction of the family assistance package. This package is of great importance in providing support for children, especially for children of poor people. It represents the implementation of the initial stages of the Government's commitment to abolish child poverty by 1990, a commitment which all Australians should applaud. Let us hope that many more initiatives of a redistributive character such as this will be forthcoming in future Budgets.

Leaving aside the humanitarian and moral considerations in opposition to further cuts in public services, the economic argument for such cuts is, to say the least, extremely dubious. As I have already indicated, the domestic budget is substantially in surplus. In the last two years, the massive cutbacks in public sector funding were based on the view that by withdrawing funds from the public sector we would have much more money for investment in the private sector. However, all the evidence is that private sector investment, especially in productive enterprises, is at best stagnant as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP). Thus, even though this Government has done more than any other government to free up funds to stimulate private sector investment, the private sector's performance in aggregate has been, to say the least, weak and singularly unimaginative. Indeed, investment in new plant and equipment, having recovered slightly as a proportion of GDP during 1985, is now at a low level. Nor should we be fooled by figures which tend to suggest that the proportion of tradable goods sector investment is on the increase when the base upon which that proportion is derived is itself still shrinking.

I remind the House that all this is happening at a time when there has been a 25 per cent increase in the profits of the private sector-that is, the non-farm corporate gross operating surplus. In all this time the working and unemployed people of this country have had to suffer from the selfish demands of the peak employer groups who have insisted on both greater productivity and further reductions in wages. Real wages have been reduced by more than 7 per cent in the last five years. The Labor Government has been able to provide this reduction in wages under the accord with very little industrial instability and substantial moderation from the union movement. Yet, notwithstanding all this, all that is forthcoming from the private sector is not greater investment but further demands from business leaders for wage reductions and cuts to public services. Rather than heeding these calls, which are no more than rationalisations for the appalling performance of business sector management, we should be focusing our minds on ways and means in which we can get co-operation between the public sector and the private sector so as to maximise investment and productive output and thereby resolve our current account problems.

Thus, the Government rejects the approaches of the New Right that I have outlined. Instead, in my view, the Budget could have been more adventurous in tackling the current account problem, but in a way totally different from that advocated by the New Right, the Leader of the National Party of Australia and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). We should note that the Treasury is not confident about the pace of adjustment in relation to the current account deficit. Pages 48 to 52 of Budget Paper No. 1 discuss the issues involved at a theoretical level but provide no evidence that the pace of adjustment being pursued is in fact adequate. It is stated that not too much weight can be given to any particular scenario and, in relation to such scenarios, it is stated at page 50:

Their outcomes are very sensitive to the future behaviour of the terms of trade, the real exchange rate, domestic and external demand, key export and import price elasticities and the debt/equity mix of capital flows. The range of plausible outcomes is fairly wide.

Given this situation, it becomes very important to promote export industries and import replacement directly through Budget measures. Unfortunately, there are no new initiatives in industry development in the 1987-88 Budget; nor are there any incentives to ensure investment in targeted industries and in those regions of the nation where unemployment is high. Indeed, in some areas there has been a reduction in such support. For example, direct grants in industry research and development have fallen from $63.4m in 1985-86 to $40.3m in 1987-88. While there is some increase in the total assistance to manufacturing of $40.7m, or 11 per cent, all of this increase is directed to existent industry plans and programs. No new industry plans and programs were announced in the Budget. This is disappointing in view of the Treasurer's statement prior to the Budget that more needs to be done at the micro-economic level to ensure the acceleration of the J-curve effect.

It should be recognised that the Budget Papers themselves forecast only a 3 per cent increase in industry investment, which is too small to deal with the magnitude of our current account problems. A moderate stimulus through the Budget for industry development would have been a direct encouragement for investment and would have allowed us to adjust the current account problem at a faster rate. It would also have allowed for an increase in economic growth and employment. Such an industry strategy could be based on the proposals contained in the Australian Council of Trade Unions document Australia Reconstructed. It would involve some additional government expenditures in giving direct assistance to particular industries, especially in the manufacturing sector, which need promotion. We could also have considered tax concessions for those companies which are prepared to invest in new productive enterprises. I hope that the review of company taxation announced by the Treasurer will treat favourably the idea of a company tax system which favours greater investment. The general point here is that, with a relatively small additional expenditure, we could have stimulated investment substantially and created more jobs.

This is especially important when one considers the employment situation. In the past few years the Government's record in the creation of employment has been excellent. However, unfortunately, our unemployment rate still remains at about 8 per cent. That very high level of unemployment could have been attacked by the implementation of an industry policy of the kind I have mentioned. I hope that the measures I have suggested will be taken into consideration in developing possible future policy for industry and that they will be favourably considered when formulating the next Budget or any mini-Budget that the Government might consider introducing between now and the next Budget.

It is very important-and it must be stressed-that any increase in industry assistance of the kind for which I am arguing not result in an increase in consumption expenditure but rather an increase in capital investment in productive enterprises. In this way the Government could achieve simultaneously a hefty reduction in unemployment and a much more rapid pace of attack on the current account problems. If industry incentives and direct assistance of the kind which we recommend were forthcoming, it would be possible to produce more goods and services in Australia for export and for import substitution. This would have the net effect of cutting into the foreign debt in a significant way. I hope that in the next Budget we will put into place an industry strategy which will help us substantially to reduce unemployment and directly to attack the current account deficit through greater investment in Australian production.

I conclude by saying once again that we totally reject the approach of the Opposition and the suggestion of Senator Walsh that the simple act of further cutting government spending will somehow turn around the current account problem; it will not. We need the direct and positive measures which I have mentioned. We certainly do not need any further cuts in the services which we provide for the Australian people.
