TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating the 1987 Budget-a Budget which, when first introduced, was received almost with delirium by the Press Gallery in Canberra; it was also received very well by financial markets. For about a week everybody was told that this was the most brilliant Budget that had ever been produced in the Commonwealth. Unfortunately for the Government, a Minister of the Crown, Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance, made a speech in Western Australia which pulled the rug from under that perception of the Budget and made it quite clear that the Government was missing a major opportunity to bring about a more rapid recovery in our external balance of payments and a more rapid reduction in our horrendous level of overseas debt. Unfortunately, history is repeating itself.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1983 and 1984, the Government had an opportunity to put Australia on a much sounder footing than it is at present. When the Government came to office the country was in recession. That recession was caused by a world recession and also the worst drought experienced this century. Things were pretty grim at the beginning of 1983, and throughout 1983 things picked up quite substantially through events that were in no way brought about by decisions of the Government. Firstly, the effects of the international recession wore off. World recovery was quite substantial and the Australian economy, with the usual time-lag, benefited from that. Secondly, the rains came, the drought disappeared and there was a restoration of prosperity, to a degree, in rural Australia. So when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was framing his 1983 Budget and whilst he was complaining that he had inherited a Budget deficit of between $9 billion and $10 billion, a claim which is totally incorrect, he had the opportunity of framing a Budget that would make a substantial contribution to putting Australia on a very sound financial footing after the ravages of the 1982-83 recession.

I shall go back over what happened precisely. The Government claimed loudly that it inherited a Budget deficit of between $9 billion and $10 billion. That was not correct. The actual Budget deficit for 1982-83 was $4 1/2 billion. A forward estimate for the subsequent year prepared in February said that if nothing whatsoever was done and if there was no recovery in the economy, no breaking of the drought and no international recovery and if no cuts were made in forward government expenditures it was possible that the Commonwealth deficit for the succeeding year, 1983-84, might be somewhere between $9 billion and $10 billion. That was in a set of Treasury Forward Estimates prepared in February 1983 for the financial year 1983-84. As it happened, of course, none of those conditions applied. The revenue forecasts on which that Treasury analysis was based were quite wrong. They were made nugatory by the buildup in the world economy and the breaking of the drought.

So in 1983 the Treasurer could have quite easily come in with a Budget which was close to balance. The Budget deficit at the end of that very bad year 1982-83 came in at $4 1/2 billion. It would have been quite possible in a good year, which it was, to budget for almost a zero deficit or at least over a couple of years to bring the deficit down to zero. Had that happened, Australia's overall debt position and particularly its overseas debt position would not have moved in the unsatisfactory way it has since. Our overseas debt would not have moved from a net $20 billion in 1983 to a net $80 billion now if the Treasurer had over those two financial years budgeted for a balanced Budget.

But the Treasurer did not do that. He took the easy path and in the course of two financial years, when things were picking up, he increased the public sector borrowing requirement-that is, extra government spending that had to be found from somewhere-by $15 billion. The deficit of the first Keating Budget, the 1983 Budget, was $8 billion, nearly twice the deficit of the last Fraser Government Budget. That is what this Treasurer did in 1983. In 1984 he repeated the procedure; he increased spending again by about 7 per cent in real terms. In 1983 and 1984, when things were on the upturn, the proceeds of the upturn were squandered and Australia was pushed into the realm of Argentinean levels of overseas debt. That is where the whole problem began. In February of 1987 the International Monetary Fund delivered to the Government a report which the Government did not make public. It says this:
The difficulties that surfaced so sharply in 1985/86 reflect internal imbalances of a longstanding nature upon which the large terms of trade decline of the past 18 months were superimposed.

In plain language, the International Monetary Fund analysts are saying that yes, Australia did suffer a decline in its terms of trade in 1985 and 1986 but that was not the beginning of the problem; those problems of declining terms of trade were superimposed on a problem of the Government's own creation-overspending disastrously in 1983 and 1984. That is where all our current problems began.

I submit to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we are going through a similar cycle; that things have eased up a bit. The mild recession we had about a year ago has eased off. There is a possibility of the Government taking tougher measures now without causing great difficulties in the community. Yet once again the Treasurer is taking the easy course. In May 1986 the Treasurer admitted for the first time that the strategy he had been following in 1983-84 of excessive growth had failed. He made it quite clear in the John Laws interview in May of 1986 that if we continued down this path we were heading towards a banana republic. That caused a shock at the time because it was going against all the propaganda the Government had put to us over the previous two years.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his address to the nation of June 1986, after he had said that the Australian economy was in a state equivalent to a state of war, asked the Australian people to make sacrifices, which they were all too ready to do in June and July of 1986. But in August 1986, in the Budget of last year, the Government squibbed the whole situation. It did not bring in the massive cuts in government spending that had been foreshadowed and it also squibbed the wage equation. So all the goodwill that the Treasurer and the Prime Minister had built up amongst the people in readying them for stern measures was frittered away in August of 1986 because the Government thought it might have an election at the end of 1986 and eased off. Then we were told, since things did not improve after that mess of a Budget, that squib of a Budget in 1986, that further measures would be needed and would be taken in May of 1987.

Some measures were taken. We were told that about $4 billion was being cut off spending. In fact, it was being cut off Forward Estimates only. A billion dollars of it was to be taken from the States. A billion dollars was to be gained from assets sales and not really from cuts in government spending. About $600m of it was in extra profits in trading by the Reserve Bank of Australia in Australia's currency. So only a bit over $1 billion represented real cuts in Government spending and none of those cuts were of a kind that were going to follow through for any substantial time. So once again we had this legerdemain by this Mandrake of a Treasurer trying to make out that tough things were being done, but once again the action was purely cosmetic.

The Government, in the election campaign, promised $500m or $600m in extra social welfare spending over and above what had previously been committed. So the Budget which we are now debating was merely a wash-up, an accounting statement, of what had been said in May, together with additional expenditures resulting from the Government's election promises. So it was really a nothing Budget in the face of a continually expanding foreign debt and a still very large external current account deficit. So, basically, the fundamental problems of the Australian economy were being dealt with with kid gloves and not with the determination that we had been told was necessary by both the Treasurer and the Prime Minister some 12 or 18 months before.

Of course, the really serious thing about this is the way in which so many people in Australia, and certainly the ladies and gentlemen in the Press gallery, were conned. I have never seen such a sickening set of write-ups as I saw on this Budget on the day after the Budget and in the succeeding days. But not all of the journalists were taken in. Certainly, the usual sycophants, who hang around the Treasurer's office and who regurgitate the rubbish that is fed out from there day by day, were taken in. Incidentally, if they do not they get clipped over the ear, hauled in and sworn at--

TALK.START.PARA: —Cut off the list.
—Yes, they get cut off the list and intimidated.
—Oh!

—Well, they do. The honourable member for Capricornia knows jolly well what goes on in these matters. But it is not only the journalists who are so treated. A senior economist from one of our major banks had the effrontery to make a statement on radio which was not wholly sycophantic of the Government and he was rung up and abused by the Treasurer that day. That was a disgraceful thing to happen, but it happens all the time. But Mr Ross Gittins of the Sydney Morning Herald let the cat out of the bag when, on 21 September, a week or so after the Budget, he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: I seem to be the only person in Australia with the temerity to be left unsatisfied by the perfection of the balanced Budget. I'm playing Oliver Sleezebag to Paul Keating's gruel-doling Mr Bumble the beadle.
In his final paragraph, which I add has very serious implications for the role of the Public Service and the role of Treasury officers in this matter, Mr Gittins wrote:

There is a subsidiary reason why the media and market reaction to the Budget was so approving: Mr Keating has converted the Budget lock-up from an aid to time-constrained journalists to an instrument of media management. Stage one was to exclude business economists from the lock-up . . . to cut journalists off from any source of independent professional analysis on Budget night.
This was done last May with the May economic statement, and it was repeated for the Budget. Mr Gittins continued:

Stage two was to fill this vacuum by supplementing the usual junior Treasury advisers in the lock-up with a bevy of deputy secretaries. These gents worked the tables assiduously-with opening gambits such as `not much to criticise, is there?'-trying to knock down objections before they got up. The subtlety of their technique seems to have stopped it working in my case.

All I can say is if that is what happened-if the Treasurer excluded from the lock-up independent analysts from the financial institutions and instead of relying on supplying junior Treasury officers to provide technical information to journalists, had deputy secretaries of the Department going in there and selling a political case-that is an absolute disgrace. It is a disgrace on the part of the Treasurer and it is a disgrace on the part of the officers who were prepared to take part in that process.

Earlier this year, with very great regret indeed and after a great deal of delay, I was forced to make some comments about the role in public debate of the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Trevor Boucher, when he entered into the debate on the fringe benefits tax. More recently, Mr Boucher entered into the identity card debate, on the side of the Government. I have not made any public comment about this because it is no longer in my specific area of Opposition responsibility, but I do so now. The Opposition finds this kind of intervention totally unacceptable. The extension of that kind of intervention to senior officers of the Treasury-to deputy secretaries, no less-is a totally unacceptable road for this Government to go down. It is the same sort of road that has been followed by the New South Wales Labor Government which has absolutely prostituted the Public Service in that State to a situation where it is almost impossible to distinguish the heads of government departments from the political functionaries of Sussex Street. We do not want that sort of behaviour in the Commonwealth. If its whole purpose is to obfuscate and to mislead as to the true nature of the Budget, it is even more of a disgrace. We are greatly indebted to the Minister for Finance who, speaking in Perth over the following weekend, said:

On the macro situation Australia is certainly not out of trouble. Indeed I'm a bit worried that the Budget might be oversold and that it will, even if the Government's not complacent, make the public complacent, and think that we can slip back into our old slothful ways and we don't have to worry any more.
Certainly, if there was another commodity price slide, the International Monetary Fund will be knocking on the door again.
A country which has a high level of foreign debt and a continuing large current account deficit is a country which has few options.

We've been a lucky country for a long time, not so lucky any more and if we don't challenge most of the absurd notions that the majority of Australians have about what they are entitled to and what's essential to them and what isn't then we are going down the Argentinean road.

So said Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance in this Government, totally discrediting the line that had been taken by the Treasurer a week before and which, at his instigation, had been peddled by deputy secretaries to the Treasury, no less-civil servants who should be neutral in these matters-to journalists who are ever too eager to soak up this rubbish. It is an absolute disgrace. At least the cat is out of the bag and at least we know that the adjustment that we are seeing-there is some adjustment-is not sufficient to keep us out of trouble if there is the slightest wobble in the international economy or if, heaven forbid, we were to run into a drought. The International Monetary Fund analysts said this:

The crucial question is whether the efforts made so far are sufficient to the task and whether the maximum speed that seems political feasible may not be too close to the minimum speed below which accidents are likely to happen.

That is what this Government has done to us. It has us on an absolute knife edge. We are on the abyss of an international debt which can swallow us up. It will take only the slightest tremor of a drought, of an oil price increase, of a drop in the world economy-anything at all-and Australia will then truly see just how far down the Argentinean road it has gone and it will hold the Treasurer of this country fully and wholly responsible for that decline.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears from the final remarks of the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), who has just resumed his seat, that the Opposition has embarked upon a strategy to promote doom and gloom. That seems to be the thrust of most of the speeches that have been made by members of the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia. I am quite amazed that the honourable member for Mackellar would question the courage of this Government to make the tough economic decisions. It is on the record that this is the Government that has brought about what is clearly a balanced Budget. That should be compared with the effort of the previous Fraser Government which left a massive deficit that almost touched $10 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: If honourable members want to make a judgment about the Budget let them refer to those who are affected by it and see what they said. Business, whether large or small, welcomed and applauded it. Investors, again whether large or small, praised it. For an independent assessment, and independent adjudicator, an independent judge, we go to the overseas money markets. What did they say? Again, it was praise, praise, praise.

It is not a question of saying that everything is perfect. We know that it is not. I think Senator Peter Walsh was correct in saying that there is still a long way to go because we do not want everybody in the community to say, `It is all over; the problems have gone'. I believe the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, was correct in saying that we still have a hard task ahead of us, but we have turned the corner. For the honourable member for Mackellar to stand up and call this a nothing Budget really questions not so much his honesty but certainly his credibility.

The people realise what has been done in the Budget. Is it nothing to give families an extra $60 a week? Is it nothing to increase the money given to every rural organisation for rural reconstruction and rural adjustment? Is it nothing to provide an extra 20,000 child care places for children? Is it nothing to provide another 5,800 places for tertiary students? I think you would agree with me, Mr Deputy Speaker, that this Budget has gone a long way towards changing the quality of life of millions of Australians. It seems that the Opposition always wants to harp on overseas debt. The facts are that we have a massive international debt, but the vast part of that debt, over 60 per cent of it, is owed by the private sector. It is owed not by government, but by business. It is owed not by the Federal Government, but by private enterprise. Another 20 per cent is owed by the States and statutory authorities. Regrettably, I must admit that my State of Queensland is in the lead in regard to that debt.

I want to refer to a specific aspect of government spending and give credit to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett), the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and the Government generally for the money that has now been allocated in the ongoing fight in the area of research, screening and prevention programs against the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS). This year, $20.5m is being spent, which is an increase of 78 per cent. We Australians need to appreciate just how serious the situation is.

Recently I had the privilege, along with a number of other members, of representing Australia at the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference in Kuala Lumpur. This was one of the important issues on the agenda. Prior to going I prepared some notes because I took upon myself the task of speaking on that subject. I read that Dr Jonathan Mann of the World Health Organisation has estimated that as many as 10 million people world wide could be infected with the acquired immune deficiency syndrome virus, known as AIDS. He said that the epidemic was just starting. Yet he points out in statistical terms that 10 million people in the world are already infected. It is claimed by United Nations experts that, before the disease has run its course, one out of every four people of the world's population will not just be infected with but will die from AIDS. This will occur despite all the medical brilliance of modern man. Despite all of the magnificent intellect, there is no cure in sight and it is believed that a vaccine is a long way off.

More than 51,500 cases have already been reported in 113 countries, but the true number is believed to be hundreds of times higher. Dr James Curran, the Director of the United States Center for Disease Control, has stated publicly that it is now estimated that 1 1/2 million Americans alone are believed to be carrying the AIDS virus. He said that studies project that one in every 30 American men between the ages of 20 and 50 have already been infected.

I ask the people who are listening to the broadcast of this debate, who read Hansard and who follow the activities of parliament to realise the importance of the Government's action in making this additional money available. To July this year, Australia has already had 562 reported cases and 308 Australians have died from AIDS. Those figures have caused some headlines. They certainly did so when they were released last month, or the month before that, by the National Health and Medical Research Council. But the thing that shocked the nation was not just the number-not just the fact that 308 Australians had died-but that an 11-month-old baby had died from the AIDS virus and that she was one of six children below the age of nine who had died from the disease. That statistic shocked me, and I believe it made many people say, `What the hell is going on? What are we doing when children below the age of one, children aged four and five, are dying of this virus? They are not homosexuals; they have not swapped syringes; yet they are the victims'. It is no wonder that families are starting to say, `What is happening?'. I believe that they will welcome this Government's initiative in allocating additional funds to the fight against AIDS.

Virtually overnight people are realising that AIDS is threatening not only homosexuals, prostitutes and drug users, but also heterosexuals. In fact, it is threatening every Australian family. It appears that it is only when the dramatic, heart-rending cases are raised that people will listen. It seems to be a traditional belief that we should never think of these diseases or talk about combating them in dollar terms-what we might save in dollar terms-because we should be talking about human beings. I can understand that, but I say to this House that, unless we start to convince governments of the world that we must look at this issue in dollar terms, they will still hide their heads in the sand like the ostrich. Whether because of political ideology, because of fear of financial losses from the fall in tourism, or because they feel politically uncomfortable in regard to such admissions they will still deny that there is a problem.

The facts are that governments throughout the world are pushing down the numbers and hiding the facts. It is because of this denial that I believe there is an urgent need to present to the governments and the political leaders of the world the economic consequences for their individual countries of what will happen if the AIDS virus is not contained and if the AIDS epidemic is not held back. I do not believe we will stop it unless a cure is found. But I believe we can contain it, and that is a responsibility of every government, irrespective of its position in the ideological sphere of the world, be it the Left or the Right. All governments need to appreciate the future financial costs that will have to be borne if the disease is not contained and if it is not ultimately eradicated.

The economic implications for the nations of the world are staggering, frightening and must be realised. They make the debt crises of some Third World countries fade into the realm of the trivial in comparison with the costs of the AIDS crisis in human and monetary terms. Yet governments and, I think, taxpayers have yet to realise the pending impact on their economies. They have not begun to appreciate the impact on so many aspects of administration and on so many areas of society. They have not thought through the impact of massive proportions on a nation's future work force as more and more people will not be able to be productive; on a country's revenue-raising and producing population; on sickness benefits and welfare payouts; on medical costs and the delivery of health services; on the costs of providing new hospital facilities, new psychiatric facilities, new facilities in prisons, additional health and support personnel; on the costly medical research training and the need to provide expensive treatment to those who are affected. There is one Swiss treatment that costs $40,000 per patient per year. As I said, if one multiplies that figure by the 10 million people who are known to be already affected, it boggles the mind.

The impact is not just in medical areas. In developed countries the impact on insurance linked to occupational superannuation and life insurance premiums is also mind-boggling. Insurance companies have realised what is happening. In America some companies are already re- writing insurance policies to exclude injury or death from sexually transmitted diseases. Some insurance companies are trying to ban homosexuals from being insured. Some insurance companies are insisting on information relating to sexual activities of would-be clients seeking life insurance. Some insurance companies are looking to make antibody tests compulsory for all large policies. Life insurance companies and their federations claim that premiums could double for everyone between the ages of 25 and 40 unless companies can properly underwrite for AIDS. The time is coming when anyone seeking life insurance will be asked to have an AIDS test. I noticed in the Queensland Courier-Mail of 3 October a report that the Australian Medical Association (AMA) is now calling for compulsory tests for prisoners and migrants and is also asking for voluntary tests on other people. So one can see an attitude developing in that people are saying, `Enough is enough'.

It is estimated that in the insurance area alone Australian companies could pay out as much as $400m on AIDS deaths in the next 15 years, so the whole actuarial basis of life insurance, retirement and death benefits is being radically undermined. This cost ultimately will be borne by the total community. Additional premium costs will be borne by the insured. It is estimated that across the board there will be a minimum increase of 10 per cent in the cost of life insurance premiums to cope with the payouts. This will add $220m to the annual costs of life insurance in the Australian community. It is an enormous cost but it is a pittance compared with the costs of health care, the costs of providing the facilities that I have mentioned that could rise to something like $1,000m by the year 2000. It is estimated that AIDS could cost Australia as much as $10 billion when all the demands are met, when we supply the hospitals, when we supply the psychiatric services and when we supply the additional facilities in prisons. That massive expenditure has to be borne by the Government and, ultimately, the taxpayer.

It has been suggested that we need to contain the disease. Yet we cannot afford even to introduce blood testing or screening for all of the migrants and refugees coming into this country. There will be no end unless we take action. I support the call by the AMA. I know that it tends to take away the rights of people but if migrants are coming to this country and must undergo some medical tests, there ought to be a legal requirement that they undertake a blood test for AIDS. I support the AMA that prisoners particularly ought to be compelled to undergo these tests. Somehow, somewhere, we will have to come to grips with the hundreds of thousands of tourists coming into this country. We may get them to make only some type of statement as to their health condition but we cannot just say, `There is nothing we can do about it'. We have a special responsibility. We have a special responsibility not only in the areas of migrants and refugees but also, as I have said, to the visitors who are pouring into our land.

AIDS is a world problem and Australia can be proud of what it has been doing. I stress that it is a world problem that has to be addressed on a world-wide basis within the Commonwealth. We need a country to give a lead. I am advocating that we need to set up an international nation by nation surveillance scheme to discover which sections of the community are most affected and to assess the effectiveness of AIDS prevention programs. We will do this only if we get co-operation. When I was in Kuala Lumpur, I found that countries did not really want to talk about this problem. They certainly would not admit that they had a difficulty. They were not prepared to come forward with statistics and I doubt whether they would really welcome the opportunity of being part of a survey. But that is what we need.

We need to undertake a program, particularly as we are a member of the Commonwealth, a great group of nations, to develop an effective surveillance scheme. We need to co-operate in analysing the medical data that is becoming available for this will reduce costs. We need to share educational material; we need to share research results; we need to share information. Someone must do this because the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association does not have the human or financial resources. I ask this Parliament to support the proposition that we give the lead, that we take upon ourselves as a nation the responsibility, which is a right of all member countries, for getting a detailed report on that country's initiatives and activities-that is, all the medical, social, educational and legal initiatives that they are taking. We should ask how they are co-ordinating their campaign at all levels of government, how they are promoting access to medical care for victims, what assessment system is in place and what educational and media material is being used.

Finally, we as a country should use our influence to target and spotlight this issue on a multicultural and a multicountry basis. I advocate that Australia should recommend as a matter of urgency that a Commonwealth countries health Ministers conference be held to begin a co-operation pact, that we have a joint physical and practical effort to fight this threat to mankind. As I have said, we are part of a major group of nations throughout this world and we have much in common but we need to take advantage of, and become an example to, the rest of the world and show what we can do if we work together to fight this threat.

We need to give a lead with the World Health Organisation in its global strategy and we need to undertake a policy of containment. I stress that matter because so many people say that there is no cure. However, we can contain the spread of AIDS. There is a need to develop a multi-nation strategy of containment. There is a need for greater co-operation, a need for nation by nation surveillance programs to be put in place. The advantages would be many. For a start, those nations that are hiding their heads will find out where they are lacking once they have completed some type of questionnaire and prepared an in depth, all-encompassing report. They will know that they are not pursuing the correct medical approach, that there is not the access to the medical help their victims need. They also need to play a greater role in education and media activities. This would also overcome the unnecessary duplication that is so costly. We can learn from the mistakes of others and borrow from their ideas.

I say again in conclusion that AIDS is the greatest threat to mankind. Unless action is taken, unless our country can give a lead, particularly among Commonwealth countries, I state the facts and figures again: one in every four people in this world will die of AIDS.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess if there were one word that I would use to describe the sentiment which this Government is attempting to wrap around its 1987-88 Budget it would be self-satisfaction. We all know that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has exuded an air of benevolent confidence. The indicators are looking good, we are told, and the country is in far better shape than he had expected a year ago, or even as recently as the mini-Budget brought down last May.

SPEECH.PARA: These favourable economic factors have allowed the Government to aim for a deficit of $27m for 1987-88, a figure which is claimed to be highly responsible when one considers that it was preceded by a peak deficit of $7.9 billion in 1983-84 and subsequent annual reductions through $6.7 billion, $5.7 billion and $2.7 billion last year. Given those figures, there is a detectable note of self-satisfaction in the Treasurer's claim that this is a rate of reduction which allows the Government to claim that skilful economic management is bringing back the deficit to a responsible level at a pace which, given the economic parameters, is successfully achieving the twin goals of maximising economic activity yet minimising the economic and social dislocation that would have occurred if the deficit had been reduced more rapidly.

Despite all the favourable indicators emphasised by the Treasurer and by the mask of confidence that shrouded his speech in this House on 15 September last, I have to admit to a strong sense of unease. I think it is an unease which can be explained by three quite simple observations.

Firstly, despite the convenient excuse of a rapidly deteriorating terms of trade offered to us in 1986 as the reason for all of our ills, today we find ourselves in difficult economic circumstances which, I believe, are more accurately explained by the extravagance and irresponsibilities of the Hawke Government in its first two years of administration.

Secondly, it is my perception-I believe it is a perception which is shared by many of my colleagues on both sides of the House-that the world economy today is in a particularly sensitive and potentially unstable situation and that the Australian economy is highly exposed and vulnerable within that order of things.

Thirdly, it is my firm belief that most Australians have a very clear understanding of the precariousness of our present circumstances and are willing to accept and respond to leadership which would take us more resolutely through this difficult period of adjustment and, hopefully, towards a stronger and more secure Australia. If those observations are correct, the Hawke Government has not only created much of what ails us today but also has produced, in its 1987-88 Budget, an economic blueprint which is seriously insufficient to lead Australia into 1988 and into a world which will, in all likelihood, be infinitely more hostile, more competitive and more unsympathetic than it has been at any time in the living memory of most Australians.

Even if the world situation were more certain, the extent of Australia's foreign debt and associated interest service commitments, the totally inadequate levels of new capital investment, inflation, interest and productivity rates which compare most unfavourably with our major international trading partners, doubts about our ability to alter substantially the inherent imbalance in our current account and the speculative nature and volatility of so much of the present activity on the financial markets, and the potential for these factors, whether separately or in combination, to produce sudden and disruptive pressures on the Australian dollar, make for circumstances unparalleled in the past 40 years and, therefore, warrant a Budget considerably more responsible and forward thinking than the document which this House is now debating.

This is a Budget which is more suitable to the comfortable times of the 1960s and 1970s rather than as an economic chart for the management of Australia through its present economic difficulties. History may well show that September 1987 was that point in time when the Hawke Government failed to understand the importance of either the circumstances now confronting Australia or the consequences for the nation, and its people, of its failure to respond to those circumstances in a responsible and businesslike manner. The year of truth for the Hawke Government was 1986, as it belatedly recognised that the Australian dollar had become a highly sensitive barometer of our economic well-being and that the foreign exchange markets were losing confidence in both the Government's economic policies and its management of those policies.

It was the foreign exchange markets that forced this Government to abandon policies and attitudes which were totally inappropriate for this country in the 1980s to begin the uncomfortable task of telling Australians just how precarious our standards of living were and to make a start on policies more in tune with reality. The Treasurer grasped around for something to blame for this about-face and discovered the terms of trade. Certainly the terms of trade were falling but, as his advisers would have pointed out, they had been trending downwards since 1973 and their most recent period of decline had begun in early 1984, only 12 months after the Hawke Government came to office. Despite that, in 1986 they became the culprit for all our economic ills, offering a convenient means to avoid any admission that the Hawke Government's extravagant expenditure programs and Budgets of 1983-84 and 1984-85 might in any way be responsible for the collapse in the dollar. The Treasurer coupled to that convenient excuse the now immortal reference to Australia's potential to become a banana republic. He certainly grabbed the headlines with that one. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), not to be outdone, completed the drama with his remarks, during his forgettable address to the nation, comparing our circumstances to those of a nation at war.

Well, if it was war, the Government's own response was rather as though it were little more than a skirmish. We saw only patchy evidence of its extravagant expenditure programs being reined in. The free-falling Australian dollar was quietly given an umbrella, and monetary policy was firmly applied to dampen the economy to a point where the current account could be brought back into balance with minimum negative impact on economic growth and employment. Many Australians, including a number from within the Government's own ranks, have observed the economic events of recent years and have a genuine concern with the Government's management responses-a concern that its first two Budgets were fiscally extravagant and its last two fiscally timid. They have a concern that there is a perceptible mood in this nation for the need for change and sacrifice and that the Government has failed to take advantage of and utilise that nationalism. They have a concern that changes in policies and attitudes are essential to achieve the twin goals of an economy in tune with a rapidly changing world, yet less vulnerable to its economic vagaries.

Australians have in the past responded positively and rationally to the needs of their country, and will so respond on this occasion, just so long as they are told what our problems are and what is needed to overcome those problems and, above all, given the leadership to take us through that readjustment and its attendant hardships. And that, unfortunately, is where this Budget has failed so dismally. Australians are not fools. They instinctively know that we are not comfortably placed in the economic scheme of things, that there is a great fragility in the world's trading and financial markets and that any serious dislocation of those markets would have tragic repercussions for a country such as Australia. I believe that 1987 was one of those rare moments in history when Australians intuitively sensed the necessity for adjustment and were willing to contribute to and work for a better and more secure Australia. The pivotal need was for leadership-to identify the road ahead, to identify our new objectives and priorities-a vision splendid, if you like. Unfortunately and tragically for this nation, this Hawke led Labor Government has let that opportunity slip by. This Budget is not a blueprint for such a vision or for the achievement of national pride. Unfortunately, it is a Budget of lost opportunities and misplaced self-satisfaction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak tonight mainly on the question of tax evasion. I want to concentrate on the now proposed extension of the tax file number. Whilst I realise that that Government decision has been brought about by a decision of the Opposition once again to break with tradition and not to support the passing of regulations once legislation has been passed--
—Did you support the ID card?

—I made the point that that is the reason why the extension of the tax file number has been brought about. That extension is something I have supported for quite some time. In a paper I wrote some two years ago I discussed the question of an ID card and put forward a case against it. I raised the question of using the Australian Taxation Office and an extension of the tax file number. I do not intend to take credit for the notion of using the tax file number, as it came from a number of royal commissions. However, it is important to discuss the notion because it appears as though the Opposition is now going to walk away from any form of attack on tax evasion. I think that is very cynical, and it would be a disastrous thing for Australia if that were to come about.

SPEECH.PARA: The result of the debate on the ID card was that a joint select committee of which I was a member was created. There were four Government members and four Opposition members. That committee provided what I believe is one of the most comprehensive reports relating to identity cards and tax evasion and other fraud. I believe the recommendations really need to be supported in the long term, particularly those contained in the unanimous section of the report and in the majority report. It is worth mentioning that some reports of recent times have indicated that the majority report was the Opposition's report. The facts are that Opposition members did sign the majority report. They were the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), a Liberal; the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), a member of the National Party of Australia; Senator Puplick, a Liberal from New South Wales; and Senator Haines, a Democrat. However, I too was a supporter of that majority report and assisted in writing a substantial part of it.

Coming to tax evasion, when this debate takes off and any legislation necessary for the extended use of a tax file number to crack down on tax evasion is introduced into the House, it is important for people to realise that in the section of the report to which all eight members were signatories, the committee was of the view that tax evasion must be tackled as vigorously as possible. The committee believed that the Australian Taxation Office had powers and information available to it that were not fully utilised. I do not think anyone here would disagree with that comment.

The fact that we know that information is available is an indication that we are not proposing another identity card by a different name. We are saying that the Tax Office has powers, has the right of access to information and at present receives that information. Its difficulty occurs in matching up the information. By requiring the use of tax file numbers in those areas, one is not simply opening up new avenues of information; it will not create new information banks or new dossiers on anyone; it will simply allow a better matching of information to which the Tax Office at present has access.

Other important recommendations need to be looked at. One of those is the question of the computerised births, deaths and marriages records. There is fear in the community that by centralising and computerising records of births, deaths and marriages the Government in some way is trying to create another dossier, or computer bank, of information. At present records of births, deaths and marriages are kept in separate registries. No links exist between States, and in many instances records are manually maintained. The information is not, therefore, as accurate as it ought to be.

When the former counsel to the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union appeared before the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, he made the point that one of the major areas of identity crisis was being created by this very problem that existed in records of births, deaths and marriages. In the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union people were obtaining identities of people who had just died. They knew that by operating in other States and utilising the names of people who were dead they were almost certain to be able to avoid detection. This was a crucial factor in their capacity to be able to operate in some of their illegal activities. Also it assisted in the creation of identities for purposes of bottom of the harbour schemes, which were to be developed later.

It is clear that there is a need to improve the registries of births, deaths and marriages in each State. Because we are a very mobile community and people move around from State to State, it is important also to make sure that there is a link between the information so that a death in one area is recorded and accurately registered against a birth in another area. In this way people in one State know that a person who was born in one State has died in another and, therefore, the records are kept up to date in every State so that birth certificates are not issued for people who have passed away.

The recording of births, deaths and marriages is important and ought to continue. It ought not to be seen as some means of introducing the ID card. It would be important for people to read the report of the Select Committee. Another recommendation made to the Committee that, to my knowledge, has not been acted upon concerned the practice of departments not informing the Australian Federal Police of possible causes or situations where fraud could arise. A number of examples were given of people who were known to possess numbers of Medicare cards. In some instances the Committee was told that one person had 23 cards and others had 45 false identities, and so forth.

The point was made that the Department of Health was aware that an individual had a large number of Medicare cards in different names, but it did not inform anyone other than to check to make sure that it was not being defrauded. When, eventually, the Federal Police came to the Department and said, `Look, we found this person has a large number of Medicare cards and we think you should be concerned about it', the Health Commission said, `We know all about it. We are right on top of this, but they are not defrauding us'. The Federal Police said, `Yes, they are not defrauding you, but they are defrauding the Department of Education'.

Quite clearly, it is a ludicrous situation where a department is aware that someone has obtained a number of identities utilising a service it provides, yet it does not believe it is in a position to inform the police. The officials of the Department felt they were bound by certain regulations and could not inform the Federal Police that there was a possibility fraud was about to occur, maybe not in that Department but in other departments. The Committee's recommendation was that the Government should examine that and see what could be done to ensure that where cases are brought to the attention of management it would take steps to bring about some investigation by the Federal Police.

The other area covered by the unanimous recommendations related to payment under the tertiary education assistance scheme. A number of accusations of fraud in that area have been made. One of the problems pursued by the Department itself was the fact that it was basically a mail order department. Because it does not have agencies spread throughout the country and in rural areas, basically it operates by mail application and by telephone discussions. Therefore, it never sees the vast majority of its clientele and does not, in many instances, have them verify information. One recommendation was that the payment should be made through the Department of Social Security. That would help in eliminating areas where people may be obtaining social security payments as well as what are now Austudy payments.

An extension of the tax file number is not an infringement of people's civil liberties. It does not contain the connotations that some people have argued, whether rightly or wrongly, that relate to the carrying of a card with a photograph on it. A tax file number would be utilised to be registered against bank accounts and in other areas where financial transactions or asset disposal or purchase is taking place to ensure that transactions are recorded and, therefore, information is able to be matched by the Tax Office.

It could be used by the Department of Social Security where payments are being made to recipients of government services so that incomes can be matched by the Tax Office in relation to information that it needs to be able to match to ensure that people are not in private employment as well as receiving social security payments they would not normally be entitled to. In our recommendations in the majority report a series of processes were recommended that would allow for the upgrading of the present tax file system so that it would become a more secure system and would allow for the introduction of a process probably about 12 months earlier than that which would have been envisaged by the use of an ID card.

In summing up, the report contains a letter that emphasises the point I made earlier with regard to the concept of a tax file number. The basis for the majority report's option-that is, the extension of the tax file number-came from a request I made during the hearing to the Health Insurance Commission, and the processes by which the integrity of the tax file could be lifted were given by me to the Tax Office as a basis by which it could calculate the proposed benefits. That is contained in the rear of the report on page 290.

What really concerns me about the debate on tax evasion is that the Opposition was quite happy to be involved in a committee to consider the Australia Card. Probably the Opposition was looking for an angle by which it hoped to embarrass the Government. At that time the Opposition was not unhappy about that situation and was willing to sign a majority report recommending the use of tax file numbers. Now that it appears that that will be a reality, the Opposition no longer wishes to commit itself to it. I believe that shows the Opposition is not serious about the use of a tax file number or about tax evasion. The only thing it is interested in is supporting, as it has done in the past, the tax cheats in the community. It is not prepared to make recommendations to enhance our tax system and eliminate fraud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Stunningly brilliant', `Keating in command' were the headlines which greeted us following the 1987 Budget. There is no denying that the Budget was politically clever and was well orchestrated so that the newspaper headlines on the day following its presentation influenced the masses. But now that the political commentaries have evaporated into oblivion and the economic analysis has begun, we can see how economically irresponsible the Budget really was. Of course, we have no need to look further than a Government Minister-none less than the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh)-to see how the Government has been undermined and has reinforced the coalition's charges of economic complacency. Senator Walsh criticised the euphoria over what was termed a balanced Budget. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I'm worried that the Budget has been oversold and it will make the public and the Government complacent and think that can we can slip back into our old slothful ways and we don't have to worry any more.

Senator Walsh went on to discuss the need to hold down consumption by saying that, if people were encouraged to spend more than they saved, Australia would be sent further down the Argentinean road; if it went any further, the position could well be irretrievable.

We must look at the implications of what the Budget has done, particularly in terms of Senator Walsh's comments. We recognise there have been no real expenditure cuts and we know that the Budget Papers tell us that the current account deficit will be about $11.5 billion. As a representative of a rural electorate, I would welcome the forecast, if it proved accurate, of interest rates falling from their historically high levels. Even if no interest at all were payable, I believe that many of my constituents would be in serious difficulties.

Of course, we are aware that the reduced deficit has been achieved by the sale of national assets and from a $1 billion increase in revenue from fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax. The balancing act reminds me of a householder who balances his weekly budget by selling his motor car and buying a bicycle or by adding to his overdraft. The payment of $1 billion does not in any way affect our overseas debt, which is still growing at the rate of $1 billion a month, and it will not affect it until there is a domestic surplus. Interest payments today are now our largest export. It is clear that this situation is not sustainable; the real question is how long this country can get away with it.

We must ask ourselves whether foreigners are going to continue to lend to us and allow us to keep carrying this debt. Today the nation's debt is 40 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). Though Australia is nowhere near in the same league as New Zealand, which has a debt of 70 per cent of GDP, such borrowing requirements indicate to me, opposed to the Budget strategy, that our interest rates will continue to be higher than those of our major overseas competitors. Of course, the repayments made by the Government are absolutely meaningless until we earn more than we spend and stop selling off the farm.

The bottom line of the Budget failed to present policies to boost our competitiveness and trade opportunities. Absolutely nothing has been done to reduce the heavy reliance on fuel as a source of government revenue, and the productive sector will continue to remain burdened with disproportionately high government-influenced costs and interest rates. The real issue is whether we move ahead of our competitors or fall further behind. Recently I was interested to read of a study commissioned by the National Farmers Federation and conducted by the Canberra-based Centre for International Economics. That study pointed out that, simply for Australia to halt its continuing slide into a severe foreign debt crisis, the balance of trade must be improved by at least $10 billion a year. That, of course, is the bottom line in the outcome of this Budget.

I believe the writing is on the wall for this country's living standards in the next century. With our indebtedness worsening, Australia is simply borrowing to preserve its standards of living. The choice now is stark: living standards must fall or trade performance must improve. There is absolutely no doubt that, if we continue the way we are going, Australia will be in no shape to weather a likely international economic downturn in 1988 or 1989. The plan, therefore, should be to identify national priorities, both domestic and overseas, that may help Australia from sinking into a debt morass from which no Third World country in recent times has recovered.

It is obvious that massive action is needed to improve our trade balance. To improve it by just $1 billion a year, we would need to see world commodity prices rise by 6 per cent, tariff cuts of 82 per cent, a fall in labour costs of at least one per cent, some major tax restructuring and, most important of all, a cut in real domestic spending. All of those things would be needed for an improvement of just $1 billion. For an improvement of $10 billion we would need to do 10 times this, simply to hold the line on our rising overseas debt.

I wish to look briefly at what has happened to rural industries in this Budget. I remind the House that this is a time when we need to improve productivity and export performance, but one result of the Budget will be the mauling of research funds for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) from $367m to $354m. An increase of some $30m would have been necessary just to keep pace with inflation, so the proposed cut represents 11.3 per cent in real terms. I am convinced that, if Australia is to remain a world leader in science and technology, CSIRO must continue to have the support of Australian governments.

The other major policy change, and an abandonment of a government promise, is in the promotion of the wool industry. A government promise to match growers' funds was broken just six weeks after the election. Of course, we know wool prices have improved, resulting in a significant increase in levy funds from growers. But once again the Hawke Government has backed away from its promise. I remind the House also that, despite an improvement, the price of wool today in relation to costs is nowhere near as attractive as it was in the 1950s.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only 40 per cent of the people have benefited from the current boom anyway.

—That is quite right. However, I believe a better example is the fact that in 1951 five bales of wool were needed to buy a normal family sedan car. Even on today's wool prices, 25 bales of wool would be required to purchase a similar car. The same sort of example can be given in almost every industry. In this Budget we saw absolutely no modifications of the wine tax and nothing done to change the disastrous effect that the 10 per cent sales tax has had on the citrus industry.
—And a Clayton's underwriting of sugar.

—The same thing has happened in the sugar industry, but a major blow was inflicted on the citrus industry with the implementation of the 10 per cent sales tax on previously exempt fruit juice. This decision in the last Budget came at a time when the industry was reeling under the effects of world price collapses. With the high levels of stock and a competitive, sluggish market the citrus industry has had great difficulty in fully passing on this tax to the consumer, and thus a further financial burden has been added to the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The community is now feeling the effect of lower prices for our commodities and is particularly feeling the effect of the attack on rural Australia. Every production incentive that has been removed over the last four years of this Government is now coming home to roost, not just for rural Australia but for the total Australian community. The lower standards of living are a stark reflection of our trade deficit. The two major policies in the Budget, the introduction of a family package and the reintroduction of negative gearing, were not new dynamic policies but were simply panic moves by the Government to counter failed policies. We remember, of course, what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said some time ago when the Opposition was trying to convince the Government to reintroduce negative gearing. The Treasurer said that Australians would not be fooled by the cynicism and political expediency of the Opposition's suggestions. He said that to try to defend this out- rageous rort-he was referring to negative gearing-`on the basis that it helps some renters is extraordinary'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—The Treasurer said that. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The great majority of rental properties are not affected by negative gearing and negative gearing has not succeeded in providing an adequate number of rental properties.
So the Government has had to go back on two of its major policy initiatives. As I have said, they are the outcome of failed policies.

We know now that there are 100,000 people homeless in this country. We know that there are 400,000 people living permanently in caravan parks. Most tragic of all is the fact that there are now one million Australian children living in poverty. So the poverty package introduced by the Government in the last Budget was not a new initiative but simply an initiative necessary to cover up past faults.

I will very briefly mention another impact that Government policies have had on rural Australia over the last few years. We all know that throughout most of the country, particularly the broadacre cereal growing areas, the last 18 months have been the most traumatic in the history of our development, with generations of farming people leaving the land or going on to welfare. We are seeing a massive flight of people from our rural areas. The Wimmera region in my electorate-and I expect the same figures apply across rural Australia-has seen a 2.8 per cent drop in population from 1981. This is particularly alarming in some of our smaller rural shires.

I conclude by saying that this Budget's biggest single item is social welfare, expenditure on which has risen by 10 per cent. Health expenditure has gone up nearly as much. In fact, welfare, health and interest on public debt will eat up one half of Budget outlays, yet our hospitals and our health services delivery throughout this country have never been in worse shape. We continue to tax our workers, our wealth producers, at punitive rates so that we can dish out funds to wealth consumers. Therefore, the real question about this Budget is: How long will its strategy remain in place and can it be successful in reducing interest, inflation and in improving our productivity? If it does not, we will not cope with any significant international economic downturn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1987-88 Commonwealth Budget is an extraordinary display of showmanship, heady optimism and large omissions. It seems hardly necessary to remind the House and the Australian people that as this Budget is brought down our gross foreign debt is of the order of $115 billion. This future that is being created for our children and our children's children is a shocking indictment of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). There is no clear evidence that the Government has focused on the fact that this debt will, at some time in the future, need to be repaid and that it simply cannot keep increasing year after year. Yet the Budget Statements-the Treasurer's own figures-estimate that our overseas debt will continue to grow at nearly $1 billion a month.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the fifth annual Budget brought down by a Government and a Treasurer which has given us record overseas debt, even by Third World standards. But if the overseas debt is not bad enough, the Budget Papers contain other figures which are also very disturbing. Our productivity rate, one of the measures of our international competitiveness, which would allow us to start the process of winding down our foreign debt, has in the past averaged more than 2 per cent. Under the policies of this Budget it will increase by one half of one per cent. How can we remain internationally competitive if our productivity is well below that of our major trading competitors? How can we describe this Budget as a good one when our productivity is one-quarter that of the normal rate?

Investment in plant and equipment, which is the engine of economic growth, improved productivity and stronger international competitiveness, is alarmingly low. It is likely to be lower than in 1983-84 when the first Budget was brought down by this Government. Furthermore, despite the pizzazz about the forecast-and I emphasise `forecast'-drop in our inflation rate, it will nonetheless be at least double that of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average and much higher than that of our major trading competitors. Our national productivity is far too low. Our inflation rate is far too high. Our investment in plant and equipment is far too low. Unless we can get our productivity up, our inflation down and our investment up we have no hope of being internationally competitive and accordingly we have no hope of bringing our overseas debt under control.

This Budget increases personal and company income tax collections by 9.2 per cent over the last year, significantly higher than the estimated inflation rate. A balanced Budget, as the Treasurer has improperly called it, that arises by increases in personal and company tax collections simply avoids the issues of productivity, investment and overseas debt. The higher taxes go, the less inclined our workers are to be more productive and the less inclined business is to make investment.

Despite all the showmanship, the outlays of this Budget are still at a much higher figure than the average outlays in all the years of the Fraser Government. The Treasurer's particular brand of optimism has conned some of the media and a sizable basketful-not all, but some-of the financial commentators. This is a Budget for the hot money financial markets, the property speculators, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Australian Labor Party branch activists.

Taxation has what we might describe as an opportunity cost. There is an immediate gain to some individuals and groups but, by virtue of the disincentives to work and invest that it creates, and by virtue of the costs associated with its collection and distribution, there is a medium and long term loss to the entire Australian community.

Australia deserves better than a Treasurer who relies so heavily on good luck. While the moves toward the lower rate of increase in spending in real terms and toward some balance in the Budget documents are realistic, taken as a whole, the Budget is a disappointing retreat from the reality of Australia's economic circumstances.

Those of us involved in national affairs have a responsibility to the country we leave to our children and our grandchildren, those in future generations, and they will not thank the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or the Treasurer for this Budget. It is a sad prospect for those men who are so desperate to win a place of relevance in Australia's history.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much has been said and written over the past two or three years about Australia's rapidly rising foreign debt, and we heard a little about that this afternoon. That there has been a rapid rise in that debt is indisputable as the evidence shows that foreign debt as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) increased from its nadir of 9.6 per cent in 1975-76 to 50.5 per cent at June 1987, with almost all of that growth taking place since 1982-83 and coinciding with the relaxation in the Government's controls over the foreign exchange markets and financial institutions. It is my personal conviction that, while I would prefer that our foreign debt be not as high as it is and not have risen at such a rapid rate, the actual level of debt is not in itself the matter of critical concern.

SPEECH.PARA: Historically Australia has suffered, or perhaps enjoyed, a particularly large foreign debt to GDP ratio. Those who express concern today about the size of that debt would have considered our circumstances prior to 1950 and back into the nineteenth century to have been a tragedy. The statistics available show that between 1900 and 1950 the debt to GDP ratio did not fall below 20 per cent and exceeded 50 per cent for 45 of those 50 years. The war years of 1914-18 and 1939-45 were apparently not an explanation for these high figures as the highest ratios were recorded in the years 1900 to 1909 and from 1929 to 1941. In passing I would make the non-predictive-I emphasise the word `non-predictive'-observation that such peaking has, coincidentally, preceded both world wars. While similar data is not available prior to 1900 there is some indication that our foreign debt to GDP ratio was probably very high for quite some years prior to 1900. All this is simply to put into perspective Australia's heavy reliance, over perhaps 100 or more years, on very high levels of foreign debt. Indeed, it may well be suggested by historians at some future time that the less than 20 per cent debt to GDP ratio over the 25 years to 1975 was a much more noteworthy event than our long history of 50 per cent plus ratios.

However, there are legitimate concerns with several aspects of Australia's present foreign debt situation, such as its composition, the investments made with it, the role of the private sector in taking up the major proportion of that debt, and the implications for Australia of the servicing of that debt. As to the composition of the debt, there must be concern that such a high proportion is in the form of loans, rather than equity, and that, in turn, much of those loans have been negotiated in overseas currencies. Mr Chairman, you would understand that many Australian farmers who took overseas loans in 1984 and 1985 expressed in foreign currencies will tell you of the fearful consequences they have faced in meeting seriously inflated servicing commitments following the collapse of the Australian dollar.

Looking to the investments made with the assistance of foreign debt creation, I must immediately admit to there being an absence of reliable data. However, the results of some research by reputable academics and financial analysts suggest that I am on fairly safe ground in suggesting that a disturbingly high proportion of that debt has been channelled into financial, property and corporate takeover activity, rather than into productive resources with employment and/or exporting opportunities. I wish to emphasise that point. To a large extent this is confirmed by the private new capital expenditure statistics published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. This expenditure has remained stagnant in real terms for the three years to June 1987 and such a trend is completely incompat- ible with the meteoric rise in foreign debt over those same years, unless one accepts that there has been an unproductive utilisation of much of that debt.

That our overseas borrowings are not being used for the creation of productive resources is little short of a tragedy when one considers our present economic ills and the critical need for wisely directed capital creation. This Government has much to answer for in creating the climate that has caused and encouraged this almost frantic creation of financial or paper wealth; in the inability or disinclination to seriously reduce our high nominal and real interest rates; in our volatile financial markets; in a continuing concern over Australia's productivity and its future direction; and in the failure to appreciate the significance of the low levels of corporate profitability which have largely prevailed since the mid-1970s.

Another concern-that of the importance of the private sector contribution to foreign debt-is well documented, and I need only state here that while this type of debt was negligible before the mid-1960s it now comprises 60 per cent of total debt. It is this factor, when taken in association with the servicing of a predominantly loan oriented foreign debt liability, which has the most serious implications for the future of Australia. Interest on total foreign debt stood at 20.7 per cent of GDP at March 1987, having risen from 5.3 per cent of GDP at June 1981. In looking back over historical data it is a matter of solemn observation that the only other time in the past 80-odd years when this ratio exceeded 20 per cent was over the period 1929 to 1935. I would feel some reassurance about this comparison if I had confidence that our foreign debt inflow had been directed into productive resources, but this is almost certainly not the case. Certainly wealth has been created, but it is a nominal or paper wealth based largely on an unaltered capital assets base.

There is an even more chilling consideration. Economic cycles are a fact of life and at a time when this nation is more marginally and more highly leveraged than at any time in the past 40 years, we must accept that high levels of speculative debt and their interest servicing commitments will add a troubling dimension to the next serious economic downturn. There is much pessimistic discussion at present, comparing our circumstances in the 1980s with those of the late 1920s. I do not want to add to that speculation, other than to say that there are far too many similarities for us to be complacent about the potential repercussions for this nation if the world economy were to enter a period of sustained recession.

My discussion of Australia's foreign debt has been largely in terms of the influence of the private sector in creating, utilising and servicing that debt. Clearly there is a public sector involvement in this debt problem. Information contained in this and previous Budget statements shows that net public sector borrowing requirements in recent years have been more than double the levels that were typical for many years prior to the mid-1970s. In the initial period of rapidly growing public sector borrowing the Commonwealth Government was the sole participant, but from the late 1970s State and local governments entered that market and gave strong impetus to its continuing growth, to a point where gross public sector borrowings reached 8 per cent of GDP in 1983-84. The recent Budget forecast is for that percentage to be pulled back to 2.2 per cent of GDP in 1987-88, and while the restraint evident in that trend cannot be disputed I suggest that four years in which to achieve a 5.8 percentage point decline in public sector borrowing is a further indication of the Hawke Government's lack of commitment to responsible economic management and a misdirection of its policies.

The policies of the Hawke Government, and particularly its failure to improve the climate for new investment in export oriented resources, have placed the Government in the paradoxical situation where it is a Labor government that will leave most Australians poorer and a very few Australians considerably richer. It is an extraordinary achievement for a Labor government of this country to have a situation where the number of very rich Australians is growing but the number of very poor Australians is increasing at a greater rate. The gap between the very rich and the very poor in Australia has never been greater. It is a legacy of this Labor Government that the people of Australia will live with this situation--
