SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Chairman, may I take this opportunity of congratulating you on your appointment to your position as this is the first time I have addressed the chamber with you in the chair. At the outset let me say that it is a very great pleasure to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) tonight as this is, of course, the first part of what is an historic Budget. It is truly an historic Budget because it is the first Budget since that of 1970-71 that is in balance. With a deficit of only $27m, it also incorporates a 2.4 per cent real reduction in Commonwealth spending. That, I must point out to the chamber, is the biggest cut in Commonwealth spending in the 35 years for which comparable records have been kept.

SPEECH.PARA: The decisions in this Budget, of which Appropriation Bill (No. 1) is obviously so important, lay the groundwork for a continuity of sound economic policy and management in this country under the Labor Government. I listened with interest to the comments of the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) a few moments ago about how in this country supposedly there are an increasing number of very wealthy and an increasing number of very poor. I find it interesting that when this Government puts up measures such as the assets test, designed to give precious social security dollars to those in need and take them from those who have no need, and when this Government puts up a measure such as the ID card to stop tax evasion, which is predominant amongst the very, very wealthy, and social security fraud and to channel those precious social security dollars to the very poor, those opposite, including the honourable member for Warringah, oppose those policy initiatives. Yet in the next breath in this chamber they say that this is wrong, that is wrong and the Labor Government is doing nothing about the problem. The hypocrisy that is apparent in that sort of stance is the very kernel of the problem for them in trying to come up with a tax policy. They have fought one election without a decent tax policy and they are well on the way to another election without a decent tax policy because they cannot face the issues squarely.

One of the most important parts of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) is the appropriation under the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet of $1.52m for the Economic Planning Advisory Council. EPAC, as it is more commonly known, was established by this Government in April 1983 following the success of the National Economic Summit Conference and, dare I say for all the redneck right wingers on the other side, it is a direct derivative of the consensus model which this Government has brought to bear upon the previously warring factions of industry and labour. As a result it has derived spectacular economic successes not only before the trade crisis that we faced but also since then in our recovery. EPAC has been instrumental in that economic management path not only in communicating and participating in the formulation of economic policy but also in the development of a whole new knowledge of economic policies and prospects which the great mass of Australians are now starting to be attentive to.

In establishing this new body the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in his second reading speech in 1983, spoke of community participation and of the need to identify feasible and desirable goals and targets for the economy as a whole. These feasible and desirable economic goals and policies are initiatives, hopes and national aspirations and goals that unite labour and capital in this country in the common good. Of course EPAC is not just another government mouthpiece; EPAC is spectacular in its success because of its independence. It has a charter that provides for it `to give freely and without unwarranted influence'. While EPAC is designed to consult with the Commonwealth Government, it is in no way bound to emulate the Government's views. Its publications, several of which honourable members no doubt have seen, recognise the key issues confronting this country and address them most sensibly. EPAC is not purely the dream of an economic technocrat in the bureaucracy; rather its research and investigation include many areas-social policy, industry, employment and other aspects of government relating to Commonwealth expenditures. One of its more important focuses is the labour market and trends in the prices and incomes arena which the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has charge of.

The appropriation for EPAC in 1987-88 will ensure that its future and its spectacular role in economic planning in this country are assured. Its role is as important today as it was when it took up its original charter in 1983 in response to the recession that the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) produced in this country through the budgetary processes of 1980-81 and 1981-82.

In the short time left to me I wish to refer to an issue which I believe it is absolutely fundamental that EPAC explore and address its mind to very quickly. I would go so far as to say, especially with the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Holding) sitting at the table tonight, that if EPAC needs more funds to do it this Government should be ready to provide funds. The issue is the single greatest threat confronting our manufacturing industry in this country at the moment: the looming skills shortage. It is now quite apparent, as this week's Business Review Weekly, for instance, points out, that there is a skills shortage that major private sector manufacturers cannot cope with. This should not come as a surprise to any of us.

It was once said that Australia was some five years behind the economic cycles of the United States of America. That is no longer the case. On a recent visit to the United States I found that the skills shortage and the predominance of employment problems-white collar and blue collar-in the United States were astounding. It was not unusual to have an inner city region of a major capital city with huge numbers of unemployed-usually ethnically based: negroes or Hispanics-at levels of 18 to 30 per cent. Yet only six miles down the road there were McDonald's, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Pizza Hut outlets advertising for full time shop assistants. In fact, some of those food chains were even taking out advertising space on billboards and so forth not to advertise their product or their service but to advertise for labour. That incongruity in the market-place, that paradox, is now confronting Australian manufacturing. We must do something about it very quickly.

Unlike American policy makers who seem not only not able but also not inclined to do anything about it, this Government has set up the employment education and training ministry. But we must go further than that. Not only must macropolicy involvement of EPAC be undertaken very shortly but also I believe that EPAC needs a special brief to explore the whole problem-the macroproblem economically and also the various instrumentality problems relating to education and to such things as communication and transport that so affect the mobility of the work force in this country. It is a task, with a goal, to which EPAC would be well suited. Should it not have the funds to look at this issue, we should give them to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in committee tonight to discuss the role of the Australian Taxation Office in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 and also to discuss something that I raised earlier this afternoon and to which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has now responded. Today I asked the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) for confirmation about the place of residence of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the travel allowance paid to him. In response, the Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: So far as the home base of the Treasurer is concerned, I have nothing to add to what the Treasurer has already told this House.

He went on to say that the disclosure of the allowances paid not only to Ministers but to other members would be tabled in due course. I welcome that, although still no time limit has been given. Unfortunately, after that question and answer, the Prime Minister is reported by Australian Associated Press as follows:

Outside Parliament earlier today, Prime Minister . . . said Mr Braithwaite was mysteriously silent about the position of his own colleagues . . . `There is a real issue, I believe, of office holders having to spend a considerable period of their time in Canberra to do their job properly' . . .
The report also states:
Because Mr Keating's situation, and that of others, could be open to misinterpretation, it was appropriate for the Remuneration Tribunal to examine the matter and clarify it, he said.

I would have no difficulty with the submission that has been made to the Remuneration Tribunal if such recompense was indeed required and if there has been misinterpretation. But I suggest that it goes deeper than misinterpretation. If there is a need for clarification by a further ruling by the Tribunal, perhaps it suggests that past practices have not been absolutely in accordance with the Tribunal's finding in the past. This is the reason for my comment.

Referring to the comment that the Minister for Administrative Services made about the place of residence of a member, I refer quite deliberately to a comment made by the Treasurer not to this House but on the AM program of 29 June pertaining to his having put his Canberra address on his election nomination form. The Treasurer said:
I have made it quite clear where I live. Yes of course I have signed where I live at this time, which is Canberra.

The point I want to make is that the 1986 review by the Tribunal indicated quite categorically-this is not open to misinterpretation-that the home base of a Minister, as it was referring to a Minister at that time, is his principal place of residence. The Treasurer has acknowledged that his main place of residence is in Canberra and proffered as further proof his address on the electoral roll in Canberra. I am suggesting that that is a normal place of residence in accordance with the Tribunal's ruling of 1986.
I entered this debate much earlier but I now go on to point out that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), in making an application to the Tribunal on 4 June 1987, wrote:

In recent years however, some Ministers and office holders who have sought to maintain a semblance of family life in Canberra have been subjected to criticism because travelling allowances are payable in Canberra. In the Government's view this matter can be best resolved by the Tribunal again reviewing the conditions of payment to reflect current arrangements applying in Canberra so as to remove any ambiguities which might have arisen in recent years.

I suggest that this letter was deliberately written in order to overcome the embarrassment that the Treasurer is currently facing in connection with the payment of this allowance. I say quite categorically that it may be that Ministers who live in Canberra and have their residence in Canberra because of their job should be recompensed. But what I am saying is that at this stage the Tribunal's rulings do not allow for that. The Minister for Industrial Relations admits that there is an ambiguity at the least. At the worst, there may have been an improper payment of the allowance. That is one aspect which I asked the Minister for Administrative Services this afternoon to bear in mind. I have been challenged on the basis that other members and other office holders have done a similar thing. All I can say is that I am referring to sub-paragraph 1 (c) of the Tribunal's ruling relating to travel allowance for Ministers which states:
The `home base' of a minister shall be his principal place of residence (and he shall nominate his principal place of residence to the Special Minister of State).

I am saying that over the past four years the Treasurer has had his principal place of residence in Canberra and it is nonsense to suggest that a travel allowance should be paid to any member, under the terms of the Tribunal's ruling, for not travelling but for staying at his principal place of residence. On evidence from the Treasurer's own lips, his principal place of residence is Canberra. This is also evidenced by the fact that he is enrolled within an electorate in Canberra.

Another aspect I wish to follow up is one that I initially raised with the Australian Taxation Office on 28 November. I asked the Commissioner of Taxation for a ruling about travel allowance being paid to a person who did not travel but who stayed at home. I did this because of the double standard involved. As a practising accountant, I know how difficult it has been for normal taxpayers in Australia to justify, in the eyes of the Commissioner, a claim for travel allowance. In fact, I had one case in which the Tax Commissioner initially disallowed an allowance for a single person genuinely living away from the rented flat which was his normal domicile. That case caused great difficulty. Yet it did not seem to me that the Commissioner was challenging a more blatant case. I wrote to the Commissioner on 28 October 1986 and received an initial response. I then wrote to the Commissioner on two separate occasions asking what was going on. On 9 July I was forced to write to the Commonwealth Ombudsman in these terms:
Over seven months ago I wrote to the Taxation Commissioner for a ruling on the taxability of travel allowance paid to Parliamentarians . . .
Despite an acknowledgment that a reply would be sent once the matter had been examined I have received no answer, despite sending two follow-up letters . . .
Finally, in response to that, I received on 15 July 1987 a response from the Commissioner of Taxation which stated:
You wrote on 28 November 1986 about aspects of how the income tax law operates in relation to daily travel allowances received by Federal parliamentarians.
These allowances are fixed by the independent Remuneration Tribunal on the basis of an appraisal of the costs that members can be expected to face by reason of having to carry out duties in Canberra.
That refers to travel allowance. It continued:
They constitute assessable income for income tax purposes, in contrast with living-away-from-home allowances the tax treatment of which is now determined according to the fringe benefits tax law.
That was not material. It continued:
The costs for which members' daily travel allowances are paid are by and large deductible for income tax purposes.
Again here I say that the travel allowance was paid for a member who did not travel away from his normal place of residence. It also stated:
. . . it has been the general practice to accept claims for deductions up to the amount of the allowance without detailed vouching. This continues to be the case . . .

I suggest that there is a double standard here. The man who is administering the tax Act is prepared to penalise the normal taxpayer in terms of the living away from home allowance, which is what the travel allowance is, the type of thing that I, as a normal taxpayer, have to justify in my books of account. Yet the Tax Commissioner is failing to interpret the Income Tax Assessment Act and is relying on the Remuneration Tribunal in regard to the Treasurer. I pointed out earlier that the Tribunal's rulings have not been applied in the way in which they should be applied. So there is a double mischief.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 10 minutes allotted to me to discuss the proposed expenditure under this portfolio of about $500m, I want to pick up two or three matters. In particular, I want to refer to the Constitutional Commission because it is a matter of great significance and because I think it is worthy of the Committee's attention. The Commission was established in December 1985, as was announced by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). The Opposition, from the word go, had some doubts about the concept of the Constitutional Commission. Basically, the Attorney-General's argument was that the politicians had failed and that we had to go outside the political arena. In fact at one stage, whilst recognising the need for some sort of balance, he talked about Malcolm and Gough being the great duo.
—Malcolm Fraser.
—I think that the reference to Malcolm Fraser probably got lost in the Cabinet discussions somewhere along the line.
—No, he went to South Africa.

—He went to South Africa. The fundamental flaw is that one cannot ignore the reality of politics. Politics, and those who are involved in politics, must play a major role in questions of constitutional reform. Professor Blainey was a fairly early critic of the Commission. In January 1986, shortly after the announcement of the setting up of the Commission, he said that the Government, by hand-picking the members of the Commission, had:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . turned its back on one of the brain-waves of history, the idea that in making the Constitution the people should be masters not only of the last step, but of the first step . . .
He was very critical. He stated:
. . . too many of the 39 names have been chosen because they are sympathetic to Labor's view of what a reformed Constitution should say.

I make that point at this stage because we are moving down the track with this Constitutional Commission. I think that that fundamental flaw is now coming very much to the fore. Those who are currently in politics do not have the opportunity which was previously afforded them by the Constitutional Convention, which this Government abandoned, to debate and discuss the matter so that they can put their views on the public record.

Be that as it may, the original cost that we finally extracted from the Government was about $3.9m in 1986-87; there were additional estimates of $629,000. These are big figures which are aimed primarily at the publicity area. I acknowledge that there is a fine line between promoting public debate on this important matter and pushing a particular line using taxpayers' funds. Of course, that is what the Government was going to do. It has a record of doing so. It was very keen at the end of 1983 to do that with regard to some of its constitutional referenda proposals. The estimate this year is up to $2.28m. That figure is considerably higher than the figure given in the summary of estimates which was produced shortly after the Constitutional Commission was established. At that stage we were told that in 1987-88 the figure would be $1.476m. There is no doubt that the Constitutional Commission is chewing up the taxpayers' cash during a year when it ought to be winding down because, of course, it must report by 30 June.

Our policy during the election was to scrap the Constitutional Commission. Obviously, the election result was such that that policy is now history. We will now look at the proposals that the Constitutional Commission and the Government move towards. We have already stated on the public record that we think the concept of four-year terms has merit. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said that during the recent election. In the last election we had a policy to promote a constitutional referendum on the question of trial by jury, which is a recommendation contained in one of the advisory committee reports.

We also stated in our policy that the concept of citizens-initiated referenda was something which we would look at and which we thought had merit. I think that that subject still needs to be debated and looked at in this place because it is a very interesting concept. It is one which, of course, may well not find favour with the Australian Labor Party because it is a concept that provides the possibility of people power intruding into Labor's corporate state-big business, big unions and big government. That is a very cosy arrangement which has been one of the hallmarks of this Government. I will be very surprised if we see a favourable response from the Government in regard to citizens-initiated referenda.

Last Friday the Constitutional Commission brought down some recommendations which we discussed in our Party meeting this morning. The decision of the party room today was to make it quite clear that the Opposition parties would not have a bar of stripping the powers of the Senate. It is one of Labor's old favourites to attack one of the basic elements of the system of checks and balances that is provided in our Constitution. It wants to rip into, and effectively do away with, the Senate by making it a mere rubber stamp. We make it absolutely clear that we will not sit back idly and see those sorts of proposals gain any currency. We see the Constitution as being absolutely fundamental to people's rights in this country. The Senate is an important part of providing and protecting people's rights.

When one casts aside the Government's rhetoric and looks at the reality of its proposals, one sees that it has a record that needs to be watched very carefully. The proposed ID card system was designed to give the Government power over individuals by allowing governments to accrue and run dossiers on people. The Bill of Rights-in fact, the Bill of wrongs-was a Bill which was going to attack and take away people's rights. These sorts of proposals which strip away the powers of the Senate will find no favour with the Opposition.

We do not believe that it is in the interests of the Australian people that the Senate be stripped of power and made a rubber stamp. The ultimate conclusion of that, the ultimate logic of those sorts of proposals, is that we would see not only a reduction in the powers of the Senate but also an increase in the powers of executive government. That is not something which we in the Opposition will give any support to whatsoever. If the Government takes up those proposals further, we will raise the matter across the country.

I would have liked to raise, and should raise, a number of other matters. I am concerned about the cutbacks in the funding for the Australian Federal Police which have been confirmed by Minister Tate's office and I would like to hear what the Attorney-General has to say about it. I would also be very interested to hear what is being done about witness protection. The Government has had more reports than it could count recommending action in that area. It had the 1983-84 Special Prosecutor's report, the National Crime Authority's (NCA) 1984-85 annual report, which stressed its importance, and the NCA's 1985-86 annual report again picked up the matter. I would appreciate some comments from the Attorney-General on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) has tried to misrepresent what the Government is about in the Senate. He talked about stripping powers but what this Government wants to do, and has always wanted to do, is ensure that democracy prevails. If honourable members want to make a comparison of the attitude of the Liberal and National parties with that of the Australian Labor Party they have only to look at the activities that this Government has enabled the Senate to undertake under the committee system. In the restructuring that is now taking place one finds that not only is there a greater opportunity for members of the Senate to be involved in supervising activities of government, the bureaucracy, the administration-in other words, the Executive-but also there are more joint house committees and House of Representatives committees. I think the comments of the honourable member for Flinders are very much party politically motivated.

SPEECH.PARA: I return very quickly to the matter before the chamber. Sometimes, and regrettably, the portfolio of the Attorney-General is too often seen as a very technical and legalistic area of administration. Most people do not realise how important this ministerial field is, especially when it comes to preserving and protecting the quality of life of citizens in this country. That misunderstanding is thrown aside when one delves into the various activities and responsibilities of the Attorney-General and his ministerial team under the new structure we now have. There is always that expected responsibility where the Government, through the Attorney-General, is responsible for the provision of legal services and the Federal courts.

But most people do not appreciate fully that this is the area of administration that is waging the fight against crime at a national level, against drug-related crimes, against white collar crimes and against organised and internationally linked crimes. That is why I welcome the amount of money that is in this measure. I take to task the honourable member for Flinders, who said that the Australian Federal Police are being downgraded and cut back. I will demonstrate how wrong he is in a moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest you ring--

—I will give the honourable member the figures. He can say what he likes when he is on air but it is the figures that count and had he bothered to read the detail presented by the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) he would have realised that he was wrong. This Government has decided, with good reason, to produce a leaner and more efficient administration but despite the tough economic circumstances that prevail, despite the need constantly to upgrade the costly technical weaponry, the Government has continued to expand its operations and has continued to improve its effectiveness and efficiency. It is waging against crime a fight that is praiseworthy. The honourable member for Flinders can argue that matter later, but clearly this Government has provided the resources, though they be expensive in human and technical terms.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is stepping up its fight by increasing the number of staff. That has been seen in the number of additional personnel who will be involved in one of the main weapons that this Government put in place in June this year, and that was the Proceeds of Crime Act. That Act came into force only a few months ago but it strikes at the very heart of crime. It strikes at the profits of drug trafficking and other organised and large scale criminal activities. It is the objective of this Government to ensure that crime does not pay. The Opposition talked about this matter for years when it was in power but did nothing. This Government has made sure that it is not just a matter of apprehending the criminal; society has demanded that criminals involved in these activities be stripped of their illegal gains. That is what this Act does and what the additional personnel will achieve.

It is good that we have a legislative commitment and that we make laws, but those laws mean very little unless we have the weaponry to ensure that they are enforced. That means spending money on human resources and technical backup. Under this measure the Government is providing an additional 70 people at a cost of $6.2m over the next two years to pursue proceeds of crimes action. It is part of this Government's overall assault on crime on a nationwide basis and it is working. I note that the Director of Public Prosecutions has already identified 80 cases where the new Act applies. We are not only apprehending criminals but also building in a deterrent for them because would-be criminals will know that they will get caught and will lose everything that they think they have gained.

Tax avoidance is also an important issue and, regardless of what the Opposition has been saying, the strategy undertaken by this Government did not rest solely with the Australia Card. One notes from the appropriations that the war against the tax avoider is not a single handed campaign; it is under this Budget that the Australian Government Solicitor has been given 60 additional staff to help close off tax rorts and conduct a systematic crackdown on tax avoidance. This additional staff will undertake tax recovery. I have pulled out some figures: some 70,000 appeals are still pending and they involve $1,144m. So the additional staff will overcome the backlog and, I believe, will save Australian taxpayers millions of dollars. In addition to this we have the blitz on bankruptcy fraud. Special investigation units are being set up and about $112m is involved just in this area.

I come to the point that the honourable member for Flinders made. He talked about cutting back expenditure on the Australian Federal Police. What is actually happening is that the Government is strengthening Australia's front line law enforcement agency. The manpower levels for 1987-88 have been increased by 104. Opposition members should make some comparisons with what they did. Since 1983 Federal Police staffing has increased by 25 per cent, an increase of 639 personnel. We are spending $150m, which is something like $10m more, this financial year. We are providing not only additional personnel but also backup by allocating special computer facilities that are needed to strengthen, further improve and expand the Federal Police's information management in criminal intelligence and investigation areas, particularly those relating to drug trafficking, organised crime and major fraud. Another $6.3m has been allocated over the next three years for specialised computer projects.

Money is being brought forward; action is being taken by this Government because it understands that it has an obligation to provide, regardless of the budgetary climate, additional funds for the Australian Federal Police, the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, the National Crime Authority and the co-operative schemes we have, such as the one with the Thai Government. This Government is putting in place the reality that criminals can get caught. It is no good having the laws or penalties that are a deterrent unless the criminal knows that he runs a high risk of being caught. This takes money, human resources and technical weaponry and this Government-the Hawke Government-is meeting those needs.

In the few minutes I have left, I make special mention of another government initiative covered by this portfolio and I refer to the ministry of consumer affairs. This issue is of special importance to me because, as honourable members will know, I raised it in my maiden speech just over three years ago. I suggested the need to take a national approach to consumer protection and consumer affairs and for a long time I advocated that this be a separate ministry. The Prime Minister promised this. He committed himself to it and I give him full credit for the total personal support he has given. I give full credit also to the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples), who is the first Minister for Consumer Affairs. The honourable member for Flinders laughs, but the Opposition shadow Ministry does not even recognise a ministry for consumer affairs. Its interest in the protection of people in this nation is such that it has not appointed a person to carry out that role. I suggest to the honourable member that he ought to think clearly through this issue and understand that consumer protection requires a national approach. Without encroaching upon the excellent works being done by consumer protection agencies at the State level, we need to understand that companies do not recognise State boundaries. They want some uniformity when it comes to advertising laws, labelling laws, packaging laws, health standards, safety requirements and warranties. That can best be done at a Federal level. This is the Government that has acted. It has been the Attorney-General, backed up now by the new Minister for Consumer Affairs (Mr Staples), who is putting in place the answer to this need and protecting the Australian community, not only, as I mentioned before, in the fight against crime but also in the vitally important area of consumer affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want, in the context of these estimates, to discuss three issues. The first relates to constitutional reform, the second to the Family Law Act and the third to the plight and circumstances of marriage counselling organisations. The first matter I want to bring to the attention of the chamber is the amount of money that is presently provided to an organisation called the Constitutional Commission. This year the Budget Papers reveal that some $2,279,000 has been allocated towards assisting this organisation in the development of proposals for reform of our Constitution. Experience would suggest that, notwithstanding the organisation's diligence, its efforts, the publication of papers and the like, unless a good deal more is done to persuade the Australian people that its proposals are worthwhile reforms all its efforts will be for naught.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the enactment of our Constitution in 1901 only some eight or so amendments have been carried under section 128 of the Constitution. In more than 80 years some 36 proposals have been advanced and many of those proposals have been rejected. As I have indicated, few have been generally accepted by the Australian people. It has been accepted or is current wisdom that referendum proposals will not pass unless they are supported by all political parties. We had the experience, for instance, when we tried to deal with the question of synchronisation of elections between the House of Representatives and the Senate, that even when the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal and National parties agreed and there were dissentients among the minority parties in the Senate, and some dissentients among the major parties as well, the dissenting view prevailed.

I very much regret that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) saw fit, when we were in Brisbane, to terminate the role of the Constitutional Convention. I recall well the circumstances, and while his view and mine might differ somewhat as to the extent to which one was able in that environment to work productively to develop proposals that might win a degree of acceptance, I would have to say that I am of the view that the proposals that will emanate from the Constitutional Commission, notwithstanding goodwill on this side of the chamber, will be unlikely to meet with success unless a good deal more effort is made on his part to involve the Opposition and State parliaments in a process whereby they will play a role in the consideration and development of the proposals.

We have a proposal for constitutional reform dealing with the term of the Federal Parliament. While there is generally agreement for proposals to extend the term of this place to, say, four years, that matter is caught up in other proposals, as I understand the work of the Constitutional Commission, to have a limitation on the right of a Prime Minister to seek an early dissolution of the Parliament if its term is extended from three years to four years and to eliminate the prospect of an early dissolution being sought by way of the Senate exercising its present rights in relation to the passage of Budget Bills. I would have to say that such proposals seem to me to be fraught with very considerable difficulties. They are verging on trying to establish a fixed term of three years with possible early dissolution in the last year of a parliament. It seems to me that this is another one of those back-door methods of trying to achieve a reform that the Australian Labor Party has had in mind since 1975. I would have to say that such proposals are unlikely to convince this side of their virtue and, that being the case, their prospect of success at a referendum must be very much doubted.

I could deal at length with the arguments as to why I think it is desirable to maintain the present system, which gives a degree of flexibility in relation to early dissolution. It is a fact that early dissolutions may not be necessarily desirable where governments have large majorities, but where there is instability with party allegiances, where there is multiparty involvement, say, in this chamber-which is a prospect that could emerge at some future time-there may be very good reasons for early dissolution to enable a Prime Minister to obtain a mandate on a particular question of principle. Yet the proposals we have before us from the Constitutional Commission are unlikely to provide the flexibility our present system provides to deal with those important questions. I will be writing more on those questions in time, but I wish to foreshadow to the Attorney that in my view they are unlikely to meet with any measure of agreement. That being the case, it seems to me it would be very much better if the Government were prepared to look at again having a constitutional convention at which these proposals could be tried out upon us and the States to see whether there can be a measure of agreement between the people who would be prominent in any debate as referendum proposals are considered.

The second matter I wish to raise relates to reform of family law. The Attorney and I served jointly on the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, which deliberated long and hard on the questions of the grounds for divorce and whether or not there should be some reform of the present grounds. The Committee, when it deliberated, took the view that there should be no change in the grounds upon which divorces are granted in this country. But I remind the Attorney that one aspect of the Committee's deliberations was in relation to whether or not the period of separation of the parties under the present Act ought to be extended. While there was a detailed discussion in the report about that matter, the Committee left open the question as to whether or not at some future time this whole question of a longer separation might be looked at. I remind the Attorney also that in paragraph 3.51 the Committee had this to say:

As related in paragraph 3.27, the Committee is divided on the question of grounds for divorce. A majority believes at the present time there should not be a change to section 48. Some members accept the reasoning as outlined as a full and complete justification of the 1975 changes, and others wished to await the outcome of the work of the Institute of Family Studies and a longer period of operation in order that the effects of the Act might be more fully assessed.
Nevertheless, the Committee is able to recommend that there be no change to the provisions of the Act relating to grounds for divorce.

I should like to suggest to the Attorney-General that it may be appropriate at this time when we are setting up new legislative committees of this Parliament that one of the matters that a committee might be invited to look at is the review that the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act said ought to take place further down the line when a great deal more factual information was available and the Act had been in place for a longer period.

The third matter I wish to raise is the aspect of the estimates which indicate that there has been a reduction of 28.7 per cent in the funds available for family conciliation centres. That means that in the area of marriage and family services generally a significant percentage reduction has occurred in the funds available for marriage and family counselling. That is an unfortunate movement and one that is in conflict with the direction in which the Attorney is able to move.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good.

—`Good', says the honourable member for Macquarie. Well, here we go. The first thing the Government introduced was the prescribed payments system. Doom and gloom were preached. That is $500m which we never had before and which was going in tax evasion. The Government ended deductibility for so-called business lunches and the shadow Treasurer at the time said that 80,000 jobs would be lost, that business would incur huge costs because people still had to be taken out to lunch. It never happened. In actual fact, more people are working in the hospitality industry now than before September 1985 when the Government announced the changes. So, once again, the Opposition was wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: We shall always remember the principal part played by the Opposition in the fringe benefits tax. It fought us all the way on the fringe benefits tax: doom and gloom again. Bob Ansett said, `Axe the tax'. There were all those predictions about business going to the wall. It has not happened and the Government's revenue predictions have been very modest. In actual fact, they have been exceeded to the tune of about 200 per cent.

The Government introduced the capital gains tax-something that has been lacking in this country for years and years. Australia was one of only two Western countries that did not have one, yet the Government was fought on the capital gains tax all the way, even though it is a very modest tax compared with that of some of our trading competitors. The Opposition has fought against all of those taxation measures that have been aimed at putting some decency back into the system. On every occasion the Opposition has been proved to be wrong.

As I said, at the last election the Opposition said it would throw huge tax cuts, which would come in in February and be paid for over time. There were no explanations about where the money was going to come from. The only scenario one could have if a policy such as that were adopted would be a collapse of the Australian dollar and interest rates going through the roof. The people of Australia were not fooled by you dummies. They rejected them for a third time and put the Hawke Labor Government back in, on the basis, I might add, that the Government was to introduce an Australia Card. The Australia Card, as we know now, has been scuttled by the Opposition-a compliant, opportunistic Opposition which came in on the tail end of the debate. All the way through the Parliament the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) did not think it was important enough even to speak on, yet now he is a man of high principle who will throw out the Australia Card because of a technicality. All I can say to that is that it was a victory of emotion over reason.

I refer to an article that appeared in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald by Mr Simon Davies of the Australian Privacy Foundation, which was instrumental, I might say, in scuttling the Australia Card. The Liberals, as I said, were mere opportunists; they were a pimple on a backside. Just to show what the Australian Privacy Foundation thought of the Liberal Party, let us see what Mr Simon Davies had to say. He said:
The Liberals proved to be less than adequate campaign partners.
That must be the understatement of the year. He continued:
Although Mr Howard had personally assured me the foundation could count on his Party's co-operation all the way, when asked to help with the underwriting of $25,000-
not give $25,000; just help with the underwriting-
. . . he refused, saying `the Liberals are in the business of promoting themselves, not other people'.
He went on to say about the Nationals:

The Nationals were marginally more helpful. Senator Ron Boswell rang the Foundation at the outset of the campaign seeking assistance for a private member's bill for a referendum on the Card. But Senator Boswell was blocked by shadow cabinet and his bill was usurped by the Liberals. When my disappointment was conveyed to Wilson Tuckey, he responded-
and these are Mr Tuckey's words, not mine-
`Boswell will do what he's bloody well told or we'll toss him'.

What a great old civil libertarian attitude. In other words, `Toe the line. Don't do what you want to do, just do as we tell you'. Here is the Opposition's great civil libertarian, its spokesman on the Australia Card, talking about his colleague in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disgusting.

—As the honourable member for Hawker said, it is disgusting. It really is. The Australian Privacy Foundation told the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) he was useless. Honourable members knew that all along. The honourable member for O'Connor never really led the debate about the Australia Card. He crawled out from under a rock when he found out there was a bit of dissension out there in the community, and yesterday--

—On a point of order, Mr Chairman: we are discussing the estimates of the Attorney-General's Department. I should like to know to what part these comments are being addressed. Perhaps it is in relation to the Law Reform Commission and the failure of the Government to pick up its recommendation on privacy.

—Order! The appropriation debates, even on particular departments, are usually rather wide ranging. I thought the honourable member was getting to the fact that the Attorney-General's Department covers most of the law enforcement in this country.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. It seems I have touched a nerve over there. Indeed, because of the demise of the Australia Card, the Attorney-General's Department now has to go out and protect the Commonwealth revenue. We had the most effective system to do that-the Australia Card-but because of opportunists like the Opposition members we have to go to the second best.
—Order! It is not in order for honourable members to refer to other honourable members as opportunists. I request the honourable member to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw. Let us talk about the second-best system that the Attorney-General must now institute, the upgraded tax file number system. Yesterday the honourable member for O'Connor said:

SPEECH.PARA: A high integrity tax file number which would be required for purposes such as opening bank accounts would be blocked in the Senate.

Today the honourable member reiterated that statement. In effect, what he is saying is that there is no way the Liberal Party will support any system that follows the money trail and that can be useful in determining a person's income. The Liberal Party says, `All you can have is a tax file number to be used for internal purposes in the Taxation Office, but if you try to use it outside the Office, which system was endorsed last year by members of the Joint Select Committee, we will not wear it'. It is about time the Liberal Party realised that this Government is fair dinkum about tax evasion and that, despite the Liberal Party's best efforts, the Government intends to proceed. It is about time the Liberal Party achieved some integrity and looked at the effects of its actions.

Before the next election the Liberal Party will have to begin telling the Australian people about its new tax policy and the source of revenue. As long as the Liberal Party opposes the measures introduced by the Government to restore some decency to the taxation system, its job will be just that much harder. I shall take a great deal of pleasure during the next election campaign in reminding the Australian people how the Liberal Party has performed in Parliament and how it has fought this issue and every other issue introduced by the Government to restore integrity to the taxation system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) might have got into at least second gear during his speech, but he stayed in first gear. I wish to raise three areas of the Attorney-General Department's appropriations: marriage and family services, censorship, and the Institute of Family Studies. The allocation in the 1987 Budget for marriage and family services is a mixed bag of increases and cuts among the various programs. An additional $434,000 has been allocated to marriage counselling organisations and an additional $9,000 to marriage education. I commend the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) for at least indexing those amounts. In the last two or three Budgets the amounts have remained static and have therefore decreased as a result of indexation.

SPEECH.PARA: However, this area of appropriations overall has seen an increase of only $24,000, due to cuts in other areas. Reductions of $114,000 in salary and running costs and of $171,000 for family conciliation centres have been made in the Budget. I could commend the Attorney-General for a number of things, as I believe he has the concerns of the family very much at heart, particularly problems associated with marriages. I understand his personal feelings on these matters. I commend him for the increased funds for marriage counselling and marriage education, although in the latter case the increase is minuscule and has been too long in eventuating. However, I ask the Attorney-General two questions: What is the justification for the savage cuts to family conciliation work; and what will be the impact of the salary and running cost cuts on the capacities of organisations and agencies involved?

In regard to my first question, have the family conciliation centres been ineffective or counter-productive? If so, surely the response should be to address the problems and not to cut the programs. If not, just how fair dinkum, to use a colloquialism, is the Government about family conciliation work? In regard to the second question, can the Government give an assurance that its cuts to salaries and running costs will not neutralise other funding increases and demoralise marriage and family workers in the process?

The second area I wish to discuss is that of censorship allocations. The Attorney-General will be aware that the report to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the consultation on the National Agenda for Women dealt specifically with the problems of pornography and violence in the media. The Attorney-General is aware of research which has shown the harm being done to children by ineffective and lax censorship controls in Australia. He has been aware that resources available to the censorship boards have been insufficient. The Budget increase will go some way towards addressing those problems. It will be to no avail, however, if the broader policy negligence of the Government relating to X-rated videotapes and the gradual decline of censorship standards in general are not addressed in the very near future.

The third area of concern to me is the funding cuts to be forced on the Institute of Family Studies. I am most concerned about this aspect. Notwithstanding the Institute's valuable and internationally recognised work, its budget is to be cut. Primarily, the cuts come in information collection and dissemination, which are its intrinsic functions, and salary and operational costs. I again ask the Attorney-General: What impact will these cuts have on the Institute's performance, and how does its performance warrant this fiscal vote of no confidence? The Institute needs more resources, not less. Indeed, I go further. The Government should be considering how the Institute's human and research resources can be given direct weight within ministerial decision-making along similar lines to youth and women's affairs research and researchers.

The real importance of the cuts to the Institute's budget is that it reflects the absence of an overall family perspective and strategy in the Government's decision-making. During the election campaign the Government declared its commitment to fight child poverty, yet the greatest cause of child poverty over the last decade has been marriage breakdown. In this Budget, and in the Government's program generally, we see no review of family law. All we see is a reduction in resources for those in the best position to provide policy guidance and assessment in this area. We see only a decision to throw money at the problem and to ignore the poverty traps created. We see the Government ignoring the underlying social factors that interact with economic factors.

The cuts to marriage conciliation and to the Institute of Family Studies outweigh the commendable increases in other related areas within the Attorney-General's Department. Such cuts are unacceptable because they are shortsighted and counter-productive. The Attorney-General owes this chamber and those who work with and for families a detailed explanation of the policy settings and the justifications for these cuts. References to the hard times we are facing will not suffice. What is required is an explanation of Government priorities and the criteria used to identify preferred mechanisms to achieve social goals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that time is limited this evening, so my contribution to the debate will be necessarily brief. I wish to mention one aspect of growing importance to a number of my constituents and, I believe, to the Australian community at large-that is, the question of foreign ownership, which has its origins in the business and consumer affairs section of the Attorney-General's portfolio. I refer specifically to purchases in recent years by Japanese interests of a number of farms, buildings, houses and hotels. It is estimated that about $8 billion has been spent over the past two years by Japanese interests, including such financial giants as Nippon Life Insurance Co., Kumagai-Gumi Co. Ltd, and Kawasaki Steel Corporation. On the Gold Coast alone, some $3 billion is estimated to have been spent by Japanese interests on real estate. I understand that all the five-star hotels constructed since 1985 between Southport and Mermaid Beach are now owned by Japanese interests.

SPEECH.PARA: This is obviously a most sensitive issue and not one that anyone would wish to blunder into, but I raise it as a matter of concern. I have carried out a great deal of research into just what amounts to foreign ownership in this country. I do not think it is an exaggeration to say that we are selling off the farm at an alarming rate. The blame can only be laid at our own door. Why should the Japanese not take advantage of a bargain? With our weak devalued dollar and the strong yen, we cannot compete with many of the Japanese interests.

On top of that, of course, consumers in Japan save 17 per cent of their earnings, compared with the Australian average of only 3 or 4 per cent. The other features of Australia are our political stability and the deregulation and the freedom of the equity markets. They have made Australia a very attractive proposition. But it has got to the stage where the Government has got to ask itself to what extent it is prepared to allow much of our central business districts-certainly to a large extent, in Queensland to only a slightly lesser extent in Sydney and to a lesser extent again in Melbourne-to be owned by Japanese interests. Again, I hasten to add that in the short time available to me I do not intend to make any blanket, generalised statements, but instead intend to raise a concern of mine about foreign ownership-it is shared by many other people-which I will follow through in later days in this place.

We have to take into account the previous experience of other parts of the world in regard to massive purchases by Japanese interests. Hawaii now is largely owned by Japanese interests. We have to take into account that Australia is too small a market; we cannot absorb $8 billion in two years and retain the sort of freedom and ownership by Australian nationals that we would wish. We cannot compete with the private investment of a great many of the massive Japanese corporations. It has been estimated that an office block in Tokyo sells for $20,000-plus per square foot-that is if it ever comes up for sale-whereas in Sydney and Melbourne the cost is only a fraction of that per square foot. I am still in the process of getting exact figures and I do not wish to be reckless in my comparisons, but it certainly is a small fraction of what the cost is in Tokyo.

I ask the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to what extent he believes his Government should be monitoring the situation. We know that last week the Government announced that it would restrict foreign investor ownership of residential properties. But the truth is that the Foreign Investment Review Board is a farce. It is very easy to avoid its very lenient requirements. It has been estimated that the approval rate for overseas investors is 99 per cent. The major requirement is that a foreign investor can purchase more than 50 per cent of an Australian property only if it can be shown that no one else in Australia would be a bidder. In other words, the Japanese can bid well above the paying price of Australian interests and therefore satisfy that condition. Alternatively, foreign investors can acquire a small Australian company-even a $2 company-and lend it money, thereby circumventing the very loose requirements of the Foreign Investment Review Board.

I will take the matter no further on this occasion except to ask the Attorney-General again to respond to a growing concern in the Australian community. It is not the fault of foreign investors; it is part of the macroeconomic weakness of this Government's policies that allow overseas investors to scoop up once in a lifetime bargains. In fact, it is beginning to look like a fire sale in this country when each and every property seems to have foreign interests showing more and more interest. It is no exaggeration to say that unless the loopholes are closed, particularly in regard to the Foreign Investment Review Board, Australians will not remain masters of their own destiny in the years to come. Again, it has been estimated by the experts that the $8 billion that has been spent in the last two years would represent only one per cent, perhaps 2 per cent, of the potential foreign investments over the next few years, particularly by the Japanese but not only by the Japanese investors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time that I have to reply I will deal quickly with the comments made by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). I found his remarks interesting. They do not really come within my portfolio, as he would know; they come within the portfolio of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I will arrange to have his remarks drawn to the attention of the Treasurer. I am aware of the significance which he places on them. Might I just say in passing that, whilst it might be a recent phenomenon that investment has increased, the opportunity has been there for some time. The honourable member would be aware, for example, that the Premier of Queensland has attracted massive investment in a place called Yeppoon, which did cause some discussion. The issue at the time was whether it was in the interests of Queensland to have that investment. I am sure that Queensland at the time thought that it was and still thinks it was. It is not only Japanese money but also money from other countries which seem to be attracted to Australia, which is a pretty good piece of the world, I acknowledge. I would be wrong to try to reply to the matter as its does not come within my portfolio. I will arrange for the Treasurer to deal with the remarks of the honourable member for Gippsland.

SPEECH.PARA: Coming back to the issues raised that fell within my portfolio, I thank all honourable members for their contributions. I found the most effective contributions were made by honourable members from my side, of course, in the sense that they were able to be constructive and praiseworthy of the work that has been done. That is no criticism of those opposite because some of them did raise a number of matters that I think will need to be answered.

I will first deal with the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), who raised a number of matters which I thought he would raise. I think he suffers from the problem that his Party does not believe in the issue he was discussing, namely, the existence of a Constitutional Commission. It is his Party's policy to do away with it. It lost the election although I do not think that that was necessarily the one reason it lost it. The honourable member used words that I think were of some interest. He said that constitutional reform is of great significance. Having said that, perhaps I might assume to have won him over to the issue. Perhaps we might at least look at it on a bipartisan basis and not have the stereotyped nonsense that we have put up with from oppositions and politicians over the years when trying to alter the Constitution in the interests of our nation. We had a Constitutional Convention that was in permanent session from 1968 to 1983-15 years of politicians, professionals, doing nothing but arguing. When some common arrangement was made about what would be put to the people by way of referendum and we got to the referendum stage they decided to disagree again. It is no wonder, as the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) eloquently pointed out, that of the 38 referendum propositions we have put to this country we have passed a measly eight in a period of 87 years. The point that ought to be mentioned-and I take some interest in it-is that I have established this Constitutional Commission, despite vigorous opposition and comments that it is a waste of time. How can it be a waste of time when, I remind the honourable member for Flinders, we have on the Commission people such as Sir Maurice Byers, Mr Justice Toohey, Professor Zines and Professor Campbell-people who are not caught up in the day to day thrust of trying to score political points? They are trying to establish what is wrong with this document. There must be a little wrong with it; it was prepared by the British in 1890 and it is a British Act of Parliament. Surely we ought to realise that something can be done about fixing it up. If Opposition members do not know that, they do know know their own history. It happens to be a British Act of Parliament prepared in the 1890s.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not say that. You said, `It was prepared by the British'.

—It was. For example, the requirement for appeals to be made to the Privy Council was put in by the House of Lords. Honourable members opposite should wake up to themselves. That is the position. The Constitution had to be approved by the British Colonial Secretary before it was submitted to the British Parliament. Do honourable members opposite not understand that problem? Do they still think that it is a great document? It is remarkable to think that they were able to get it right back in the 1890s. But the Opposition knows that Australia has come into independent sovereignty and has a lot of problems from the point of view of understanding how it might grapple, for example, with the national economy, or trade and commerce between the States. All these matters are of significance but why do honour- able members opposite belittle their fellow Australians who have assembled to look at the document, who took evidence from a large number of Australians, who prepared reports which I think are very good, even though they have been criticised here? The honourable member for Dundas got quite pessimistic and said that it is all a waste of time. I do not think it is. When we go to the Australian people next year on this matter-I would like to do this around December because of time constraints-I would like to put to them the proposition that we have a four-year term of Parliament. I think most people are saying that that is a good idea. I say to honourable members opposite, `If you think this is a good idea and I think this is a good idea, we have a chance of getting it carried'. The next matter mentioned by the honourable member for Dundas was trial by jury. I do not think that would be a contentious matter to put to the Australian people. Why should they not have the right to trial by jury?
—It is our policy.

—It is Opposition policy now that it has found out about it. I come now to the matter of religious freedom in the States. Do Opposition members not think that that right should be included in the Constitution? Following a judicial interpretation on the matter, that is no longer deemed to be the situation. Do Opposition members not think that people should have the right to free speech and the right of assembly incorporated in the Constitution? But those things are not in the Constitution. Do Opposition members not think that the Australian people should have the right to vote? That right is not in the Constitution either.
—You are back to the Bill of Rights.

—It would be a dreadful thing to have a Bill of Rights that provided for people to have the right to vote, the right to free speech and the right of assembly! It is typical of the Opposition to adopt that sort of antediluvian attitude. It might be a little contentious to put forward the suggestion that all elections in Australia be held on a democratic basis and that electorates be permitted to have a tolerance above or below the quota of no more than 10 per cent. Some propositions might attract a little discussion, not in respect of their fairness or equity but because some members who have won seats by means of a gerrymander might lose them. Those propositions ought to be put to the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: We also ought to remove from the Constitution outmoded provisions such as the one that states that every law can be disallowed by Her Majesty the Queen. At present laws can be reserved for the approval of Her Majesty the Queen. I do not think such a provision is relevant. If proposals were put forward to change those sorts of provisions, we would be able to make a flying start in doing something about the Constitution for the first time in 87 or 88 years. Is there anything horrendous about any of those propositions? Of course there is not. However, it took the Constitutional Commission to identify these issues. In the past political parties have lambasted each other at constitutional conventions in trying to come to a decision about these matters. For 15 years it cost the Australian people an arm and a leg in financial terms for us to discuss matters on which we were not even able to agree about whether they should be put to the Australian people. It is ridiculous for the Opposition to talk about the cost of putting such propositions to the people by way of referendum when one considers the enormous amount spent on allowing professional politicians the luxury of arguing with each other. It is a ridiculous situation. That is why it is about time the politicians were excluded from performing that role and the people were allowed to express their opinion about what ought to happen to the Constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Thank you. It would be a good idea if the Opposition were to concentrate on those matters I have mentioned. I think they have some merit. I do not think the Australian people will object to them. Putting those matters to the Australian people would afford the Opposition an opportunity to do something for the nation instead of uttering such nonsense as the people cannot trust whatever the Government puts to them. Persons of the ilk of the Premier of Queensland will say, whatever proposition is advanced, `I do not know what it is, but it is outrageous, and therefore you ought to vote against it'. We have put up with that sort of nonsense for years.
—It sounds like Hawke and the ID card.
—I know that even the honourable member does not agree with the Premier of Queensland, and that is to his credit, but look at what has happened to him.
—I do.

—It is no wonder you have so much Japanese investment. Much can be done for this nation if we put aside our political posturing and ask the people to consider calmly whether they think these propositions are fair.
—That is what the honourable member for Dundas said.

—The honourable member for Dundas said that to put such propositions is a waste of time. He said that only eight out of 38 propositions have been carried in the past 87 years. He posed the question: Why do you want to try again? I want to try again and do it a little differently. Such propositions will have no hope of being passed if members of this Parliament continue to say how bad they are and to point to the fact that they have not been passed on previous occasions. Opposition members simply oppose such propositions because they are in opposition. They question the point of having the Constitutional Commission. During the last election campaign they said they would abolish the Commission. The Opposition has no interest in the Commission. In fact, it is rather ridiculous of Opposition members to talk during consideration of the Estimates about a body that they propose to do away with. I cannot imagine anything more ridiculous.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Flinders raised two matters. He said that it had been reported in the Press that it was proposed to reduce the Budget allocation to the Australian Federal Police. The honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) made it clear that no reduction was proposed, that what was mentioned was a bid for resources. In fact, the Australian Federal Police has been allocated another $9.3m and an extra 104 staff. So it is wrong for the honourable member to suggest that any cutback is proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was concerned only because Senator Tate's office confirmed the article.

—I have informed the honourable member of the true position, and he will now be able to correct anyone who says anything different. The honourable member for Flinders also raised the matter of witness protection, which is causing some concern. I am advised that witness protection is a matter primarily for the Australian Federal Police; it provides full witness protection. The National Crime Authority relies for such protection on arrangements made with the New South Wales and Victorian police forces. The matter is being examined, I understand, by the Australian Police Ministers Council. I understand also that during the last Parliament the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority indicated that it would be conducting an inquiry into witness protection in Australia, and it has sought submissions from the Commonwealth and State law enforcement agencies. The chairman has reported that the committee would be resuming its inquiry in September of this year. The Government is anxious to get some further advice as to what should be done, as it acknowledges the seriousness of the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from raising the matter of the Constitutional Commission, the honourable member for Dundas referred also to the problems in the family law area. He mentioned the recommendations brought down by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. I propose in the near future to introduce some amendments to the Family Law Act. I would think that they will be relatively minor amendments. The most important thing that we must acknowledge in the area of family law is the burden placed upon the judiciary by those parties who cannot reconcile their differences. They constitute about 7 per cent of those who seek a divorce, while those who are able to reconcile their differences constitute 93 per cent. Those 7 per cent probably cost the community some $90m. The number of judges has been increased from 25 to 55. Legal aid would cost the Australian community about $60m also. One can see that an enormous amount of resources is required by a relatively small number of people who cannot solve their own problems. The Australian taxpayer must also meet the cost of social security payments that result form that situation. As the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) said, when a family breaks up it creates poverty. Such people have enormous needs, and that creates numerous problems.

It is tragic to think that one family law judge has been murdered and the wife of another judge has been murdered. Bomb threats to family law courts in Sydney are made frequently. Court officers seem to spend more time on the street than in the court building because of the security risk. I am keen for people to understand the great pressure that judges are under. It is important to acknowledge that the Government wishes to give a high priority to the family. It is a little late to do anything once the parties have reached the divorce courts. Some people take the view that the parties may come together when they get to court. By the time the parties get to court we as legal practitioners are concerned with how they might make the required adjustment and how such things as custody, maintenance and property settlements will be dealt with. Such issues create heat between the parties. The parties having decided that there has been irretrievable breakdown of the marriage, the process of going to court is costly and draining in human resources.

I congratulate all those who work in that area on their dedication in trying to help the parties. In that context, I propose to introduce amendments to the legislation to provide for delegation of authority to grant divorces where the parties can come to agreement quickly between themselves, following the necessary counselling and conciliation. The Family Court judges will be relieved of some of the burden by the creation of the position of master. At present, the courts of summary jurisdiction deal with 80 per cent of all maintenance cases. The proposed amendments will allow parties in agreement to have their divorce granted in the courts of summary jurisdiction. That will relieve the family courts of much of their present burden and delays. It is unwise to allow to continue delays of 2 1/2 to three years. The present system is using a lot of financial resources and, as I said, very few of the people involved are really in dispute. I notice that in Western Australia about 66 per cent of the people appear in person, having been able to solve most of their troubles. That is an effective result.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about contested cases in magistrates courts?

—Contested matters would have to go to the Family Court. I do not think the States can be burdened with all that work because they have plenty of other work to do in courts of summary jurisdiction. I think the honourable member for Dundas talked about family and marriage guidance and went on to refer to conciliation centres. This picks up a number of remarks made by the honourable member for Macquarie. I am unable to give the marriage guidance people what they need. They do an enormous amount of work for nothing. They are extremely valuable and ought to be given more encouragement. I am able to give them a 9 per cent effective increase this year. I recognise that that is not enough but that is the best I could get from the Budget decisions. I know they need more. Their history shows that they have always been working basically without reward. They help this country by giving marriage guidance when the parties first find it difficult to cope with the problems they face.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Dundas also mentioned the two conciliation centres. There is one in Victoria and one in New South Wales. There is a difference between the two. The centre at Noble Park in Victoria was developed as a model based on mediation. I looked at it and I think it is doing good work because basically it is part and parcel of the Dandenong Family Court. A number of matters have been referred by the court to the Noble Park conciliation centre. So it is experienced and very well qualified to deal with parties that are already part of the court process. Whilst the centre is a model, it obviously has been a great asset to the Dandenong area. The difficulty is that it costs $420,000 for one centre. I think this is good value. The centre is related to the Dandenong Family Court and that is where the value is.

Wollongong adopted a different model which concentrated on the delivery of counselling and advisory services on a one stop basis. An evaluation found that that model was duplicative of existing community agencies. It was not related to a family court as was the centre at Noble Park. On that basis, Noble Park's funding has been continued but, following evaluation, the funding for Wollongong has not been continued. As I said, they were both pilot projects and assessed on that basis. We would all agree that we would be much better off if we could reduce pressure on the court by increasing marriage guidance for the parties.
The Institute of Family Studies was mentioned. I understand that the reduction was about $100,000. That is relatively small. The Institute of Family Studies is doing good work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shouldn't it have been increased?

—We have to look at the actual work it is doing. It is doing excellent work. I think that will be maintained. In fact, it is a statutory requirement under the Family Law Act. The honourable gentleman has taken a keen and valid interest in censorship. He did not mention it but I know that he knows that a committee of the Parliament has been dealing with censorship.
