DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Welcome Home Parade for Vietnam Veterans-Queensland Police Force

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to draw the attention of the House to a unique event which took place in Sydney last weekend, the national welcome home parade for Vietnam veterans, which saw a record breaking turnout, given the expectations associated with the buildup to the parade, of well over 100,000 people from Sydney and around Australia to observe a march of well over 22,000 Vietnam veterans. Whilst we did have an excellent bipartisan motion in both Houses of Parliament prior to the national welcome home parade, I take this opportunity to offer congratulations to Mr Peter Poulton, the Chairman of the Australian Vietnam Forces Reunion Committee, the key committee organising the huge exercise associated with bringing about the national welcome home parade, to all the members of that committee and to all the others who participated or lent their support by one method or another, including the Sydney City Council, the Chief Commissioner, Sir Eric Neal, and other commissioners and staff of that Council. I add that the Government, and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in particular, assisted through the provision of transport to bring hundreds of veterans to Sydney. This too was greatly appreciated. As a result, we saw a magnificent gesture of warmth, affection and support for Vietnam veterans who were extended a long overdue welcome home to Australia in a very symbolic and direct way.

SPEECH.PARA: It was very moving to participate not only in the main parade and the main receptions associated with that parade, but also in the very moving dawn service at which the address was given by former Brigadier Kahn. His address, as remarked upon by the Minister present at the dawn service, myself and others, was truly memorable and set the scene for a very moving dawn service at the Cenotaph at 4.30 a.m. last Saturday. It also set the scene for the subsequent regimental memorial service, the parade itself and the other events of the weekend, including what I understand was a highly successful concert in the Domain. Unfortunately, functions in my own electorate of Farrer caused me to miss that particular concert. I think that the Parliament should take this opportunity-certainly I do as shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs-to extend congratulations to all involved with the national welcome home parade.

I would just like to add two things which should be recorded. I did not make a big issue about them prior to the parade because I do not think it should have become a vehicle for pushing special political barrows. There are four categories of people who went to Vietnam who have not received full recognition, particularly the Vietnam Service Medal. They are, firstly, the Citizen Military Forces observers; secondly, a small contingent of Royal Australian Air Force personnel who flew in and out of Vietnam; thirdly, war correspondents. Given the fact that war correspondents by convention were always deserving and recognised by way of awards in World War II, in Korea and in Malaya, this should happen again in the case of Vietnam. Fourthly, there are those who served on HMAS Sydney and other support ships operating between Australia and Vietnam. To be fair, that last category has now got, under amendments to the Veterans' Entitlement Act, repatriation cover and the return from active service badge. But the Minister for Defence has recently indicated in a three-page letter that he cannot agree to amend the royal warrant to allow for the issue of that particular medal. I have discussed this informally with the Minister at one of the receptions in the immediate aftermath of the parade. I hope that he might think again about an award for those four categories to give proper and due recognition to them in the aftermath of the national welcome home parade. It would be seen as a very appropriate gesture for the Minister to do that and also to examine another dimension in terms of medals which would not be proper for me to raise at this stage ahead of 1988.

Finally, I add that those who did march have a right to feel that they gave very dedicated and disciplined service for their country in a very difficult war in Vietnam. I make no apology for myself, amongst others, for having participated in that controversial conflict. I know in my heart that, whatever the rights and wrongs and although the outcome was a defeat for the then South Vietnamese Government and for the allied forces, those people who are in Vietnam tonight will know how difficult, extreme and harsh are the economic circumstances they face under with the North Vietnamese communist Government.
